147046977.review:
Un RPG acerca de la vida que tienen que afrontar pacientes y sus familiares en un hospital, sobre lo dificultoso que es afrontar la posibilidad de que pierdas a tus seres queridos, o el aceptar que ya no están aquí. También se tocan otros temas como la soledad, el arrepentimiento, la xenofobia y el prejuicio por eventos pasados, etc.

Todo eso mezclado con un mundo de fantasía cómico y colorido que tendremos que explorar al estar conectado con los eventos del mundo "normal".

Por otra parte, el pixel art está muy lindo y la banda sonora tiene temitas y canciones de buena calidad también (la compositora ha trabajado en juegos como Plants. vs Zombies, To the Moon, Deltarune..., así que te puedes dar una idea)

Lo que no me gustó mucho fue que los personajes principales no les parece impactar mucho lo irreal que luce el otro mundo, ni tampoco se siente que estén sufriendo físicamente de estar moviéndose en todo momento; casi nunca lucen cansados.
Y no me desagradó la jugabilidad, pero creo que abusaron un poco de la idea de "X personaje necesita Z ítem, entonces debes ir a buscarlos", es muy recurrente bro.

Hay otras cosas que no me gustaron y otras que sí, pero para concluir: está bueno, lo recomiendo XDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDD

Sometimes the controls can be a bit janky but I still had an absolutely wonderful time delving into these worlds.

Vivid jaw-dropping pixel art, cohesive wholesome music, and lugubrious stories that will toy with your emotions. I have only ever ugly cried to a few games before, and this is one of them.

As an achievement hunter, there is really only one extremely easy-to-miss collectible. Otherwise, most points of no return are clearly marked. A bit disappointing that the game doesn't have windowed full screen, or the ability to show the steam overlay, but that is merely a limitation of the game engine. Those complaints pale in comparison to the amazing storytelling of this gorgeous game, and I'm glad to have played this directly after playing Mr. Saitou. Both games are a must play, and I'm glad to have gotten 100% completion in both of them.

145442039.review:
I had hopes for Rakuen when I first picked it up, considering its positive reception and unique premise. However, after spending some time with the game, I can confidently say that it's not my cup of tea at all.

The first issue I encountered with Rakuen is its overwhelming cuteness factor. Now, I understand that cute can be charming and endearing in the right context, but Rakuen takes it to a whole new level.

My biggest gripe with Rakuen, however, is its gameplay. The game heavily relies on tedious fetch quests, which quickly turned what should have been a heartwarming experience into a mind-numbing chore. It felt like I was endlessly shuttling back and forth between characters, collecting items, and solving mundane puzzles just to progress. This not only made the game feel monotonous but also detracted from the emotional impact of the story.

I went into Rakuen hoping for a unique and emotionally engaging experience, but what I got was an overdose of repetitive gameplay. It's not a game for everyone, especially if you prefer more depth and substance in your gaming experiences. If you're looking for a title that's heavy on charm but light on substance, Rakuen might be right up your alley. Unfortunately, it just wasn't for me, and I can't recommend it to those who share my gaming preferences.

143789701.review:
Rakuen is a pixelated story-driven game that focuses on the lingering regrets of the sick people in hospitals. You go through multiple small stories each one focusing on a different character. The story is well written and you can really feel how the characters feel. It's a really emotional game and a really good one at that. 

There is however one thing I should point out. The game is also heavily focused on puzzle solving, backtracking and a lot of randomly moving around until you find where to go. This is especially clear at the beginning of the game. It can be quite frustrating at times and the game can even game over you which I feel is wrong for an emotional story game. 

However the emotional parts overshine the frustrating puzzle parts of the game and makes it still very enjoyable to play. You could also just look up a guide to find out where to go if you feel lost. All in all the game is fantastic and I would recommend playing it.

Llegué sin expectativa alguna, pensé que solo sería un jueguito llamativo tipo RPG-Maker del montón y terminó siendo una de las experiencias narrativas más impresionantes que he llegado a disfrutar en steam.

Todo en él es precioso, desde el arte, la música, el concepto; el poder sentir a través de los diálogos la pureza del niño protagonista y el amor incondicional de su madre; la dualidad entre la esperanza y simplemente dejar de luchar por lo agotadora que puede ser la batalla contra los malos momentos. 

Recomiendo para aquellos que disfrutan las aventuras narrativas. El gameplay es tedioso porque es muy ambiguo, (requerí guía para poder avanzar en varias partes), a veces con vaivén aburrido pero se complementa con todas las cosas bonitas que tiene por ofrecer.

I played this game because I had a very strained relationship with my mother somewhere along my teenage years and in the end it came to be that we never saw each other anymore, nor had anymore contact as well. I decided to give this game a try because I wanted to feel what was like to have that bubbly bond between a mother and son again, back when I was younger. 

Well, it gave those feelings back to me, and it gave it like a sucker punch to the guts. 

I still listen to the OST from time to time and it still reminds me of times of childhood back before when everything became so terrifying.

Give your mother a hug or a call at least if you can before you can never anymore.

137966166.review:
The conclusion of Rakuen absolutely has me reeling. This game is just beautiful and so well written. It's about love, loss, redemption, and the impact we have on eachother. 
I was drawn in immediately by the story and I'm so happy that the story paid off. The colorful art and thoughtful level design added complexity to the atmosphere and storytelling. A game hasn't made me cry like this in years. I can't say much about the story without giving spoilers, but just... wow. 
It only took me 10 hours to play but I'll remember it for a long time.  If you want to ingest a rich, wholesome story that will emotionally wreck you for a couple hours, I highly recommend this one! Rakuen is going straight into my top ten favorite games. I'll definitely be playing it again!

All in all, I liked this game. It has a pretty strong story, amazing art style and good music.

You learn about people in the hospital and their personal stories. There is an alternate fantasy world which is beautiful and super cute! The characters there are my favourite, especially the cave/sky buds.

But I wasn't expecting there to be sections where things take a darker turn. In a few "flashbacks" there is a creepy atmosphere and music. For example, red writing appears on the wall; footsteps can be heard off screen. I can't call it scary, but it did put me on edge a bit (yes, I'm a wuss). I had to blast some Lionel Richie because I couldn't stand to hear the creepy droning any longer.

It dampened my enjoyment of the game a bit because there was too much contrast between the cutesy elements and the creepy elements. It felt odd, like who is this game geared towards?
And when I say cutesy, I mean very cutesy - bordering on corny sometimes with the song lyrics (and I'm not saying that as an insult). Personally, I like to play games to relax, so I will take corny over creepy any day!

Luckily, these dark sections are not there for every character. I was relieved. Even towards the end, it was better balanced in its design; there were dark parts to the story but it wasn't trying to be a horror game.

Those personal preferences aside, the stories were touching and there was a satisfying closure in the finale. Everything came together.

I've seen some complaints about the slow walking speed and the constant back-and-forth when completing tasks, but I didn't really have an issue with that. There was only one time I can think of where the back-and-forth was a bit of a nuisance. Other than that, I was okay with walking around the areas. 

Rakuen was an interesting experience and I'm glad I played it. I think the story, characters and style will give a lasting memory for whoever plays it.

Now to do it all over again to get the damn achievements I missed.

135864097.review:
[h1]I am emotionally compromised[/h1]

I thought I was ready. I was not ready. Haven't cried that much at a video game since To the Moon. Like, a gross amount of tears and snot. [b]Man.[/b]

Amazing OST, as to be expected from Laura Shigihara. Super cute sprites and character designs. Puzzles are just the right amount of challenging - though I'll admit I got stuck in the house a couple times and had to look up what to do.

The plot is where Rakuen really shines. Of the 5 plotlines, there's likely to be at least one or two that will mess you up properly. Everyone can relate to the very human stories told in Rakuen, despite them being explored through a fantasy world lens. There are tie-ins to real-world events that ground this story in reality. And often, I didn't realize the implications of what I observed earlier in the game until much later on. Rakuen is a game that lets you connect a lot of the dots on your own before revealing its story, which lets you connect with it on a much deeper, more personal level.

Couple small frustrations in terms of the early game being a pain to navigate. Found myself often wanting a run button, especially with all the backtracking required. Navigation gets substantially easier after you acquire tools and fast travel spots, but yeah - kind of a drag early on, which is a total shame because the mid to late game is really where it's at.

Another minor complaint is that since some items are only collectible in the areas you can only access once, I missed out on my collection hunter achievement T_T perhaps on a replay, though, if I can steel myself enough to run through this emotional rollercoaster again.

10/10. Buy tissues and stay hydrated, because this game takes you on a wild feels trip -- whether you think you're ready or not.

135743784.review:
Rakuen is a small JRPG about a young boy in a hospital, who is led to a fantasy world by his children's book Rakuen about Morizora's Forest. With his mother, he wants to ask Morizora, the guardian of the forest, for a wish. On their adventure, he travels back and forth between the two worlds, helping the patients and visitors of the hospital: Gemma, a woman who has been in a coma for a long time and whose husband Winston never leaves her side. Tony, a grumpy old man with a broken music box that he protects with his life, and whose family is torn apart. Kisaburo, a man who is losing his mind and often sneaks out of the hospital to dig in the ground. And Sue, a little girl who has a large marble collection, but has never been able to say goodbye to her best friend. 

The game is divided into five sections and in each one you help one of the patients in the hospital. The characters are all thought out with a lot of love and it's a wonderful experience to have their story told in the hospital and the fantasy world in different ways because each character also exists as a magical being in Morizora's forest. This makes a point of why I think the story is so incredibly beautifully crafted. All of them have something that is bothering them during their stay in the hospital and those situations can often occur in daily life, which is why you can put yourself in their situations really well. This has led to the fact that I often started crying and for a few minutes I was not able to continue the game. Especially because now and then you could only realize and process certain details and story connections of the characters later. Even though the game is incredibly emotional, there were moments when I laughed as well because situations and dialogues were just hilarious, but still fit into the world. The only thing that bothered me about the characters and the story was that certain things were not developed enough in my opinion. For example, Sue's story was relatively short compared to the others, raised an unanswered question, and consisted mostly of cutscenes. This was very rarely the case, but there could have been a bit more depth. 

The adventure is designed in such a way that you not only travel between the two worlds, but often have to solve puzzles as well. The puzzles are relatively easy, but still require more thought from time to time. You often have to explore your beautiful surrounding to get clues and progress. Additionally, not only do you find important items for the story, but also pets and other items that you can collect for a community room in the hospital to fill over time. 

As already mentioned, Morizora's forest is fantastically designed. The world really looks like a small forest with the most diverse creatures you can only dream of: the Leebles, various plants, bears, sirens and more. The atmosphere is often very relaxing and it's just fun to walk around the areas and look at everything. Whereby a point of criticism would be that I would have liked an option to run faster. Every now and then it was a bit annoying to run back and forth between places at snail's pace. But back to the atmosphere: The game also takes place in the hospital and in retrospective memories and I'll be honest, some sections were creepy from time to time. The game is definitely not a horror game, but darkness and loud clock ticking for example can create tension. A lot is also brought out by the music in the game and I love the music in this game. Laura Shigihara not only created the game, but also composed the music and sang the songs. Especially the songs that are meant for the individual characters are so incredibly touching and even made my crying worse. 

In summary, I can recommend Rakuen to anyone who likes small RPGs, puzzles and emotional stories. Especially the emotional aspect is something to be prepared for. I can assure you that if you buy the game, you should also buy a box of tissues. Rakuen is a game where I wish I could forget everything and play it again without any knowledge. Laura Shigihara has definitely created a small masterpiece with Rakuen.

I don't think that I've been emotionally impacted this much by a story since the To the Moon games. Rakuen is an absolutely beautiful story-rich journey about a young boy who is hospitalized and a colorful cast of characters who are in the hospital with him. In the parallel world from the book Rakuen, the boy's favorite childhood story, the boy goes on adventures with his mom and meets magical, otherworldly versions of the other patients at the hospital. As he discovers their stories and crafts friendship while fulfilling their wishes, he aquires the runestone songs necessary to get his own wish fulfilled by the Guardian of the Forest. It's a beautiful game about hope, the stories we leave behind, and the little world's we build and share with others. A huge thank you to Laura Shigihara for allowing us into this little world of Rakuen that she built and for allowing us to continue exploring it in Mr. Saitou. 8/10

Update: Also, if you haven't played Mr. Saitou, it's a shorter and a bit more light-hearted game in the same universe which I also highly recommend.

133159806.review:
What an incredible game! The story is absolutely amazing and emotional, though most of it is delivered through text dialogue, so be prepared to do lots of reading! The soundtrack is equally brilliant! 

The gameplay is pretty good, too, though it might not be everyone's cup of tea as it is in essence a puzzle game. More specifically, it gives off point & click adventure game vibes, with most of the puzzles being 'inventory-style', with some pure logic puzzles here and there, except you control your character's movement using directional keys instead of the mouse, with a few of the puzzles making use of this type of movement. In addition, unlike point & click games where collectable items are scattered all over the screen, items in this game are hidden in containers such chests/ cabinets/ drawers, with the exception of some natural materials which can be found in plain sight all over the forest. You also don't need to choose which items to use from your inventory. Once you've collected the required item, just interact with the right character/ object and the option to use said item should be available, with the exception of keys which are used automatically. 

As a huge fan of puzzle games, I found the puzzles very enjoyable to solve. They lean toward the easy side, though those who have little experience with puzzles might still get stuck at points. Nevertheless, the story is so good that I think it's worth playing through the game even if you don't like puzzles.

My only complaint is that the default walk speed is very slow, and considering how much you have to walk back and forth from area to area, walking can get pretty tedious, which is why I HIGHLY recommend you download AlexanderNorup's [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1358605227] Sprinting Patch [/url]. If I'm not mistaken, the patch will automatically set the game language to English, but if you're reading this review, then you're probably going to play the game in English, anyway.

Overall, it's a very good game made with passion by just one person. Some technical difficulties (trust me, you don't want to have a 4K screen), but it doesn't matter. The story, the music, the overall charm works wonder. 

A very solid 8/10, worth its price (even full price), the only reason not to play this is if you don't have 6-8 hours. But if you've played every J-RPG/RPG maker game with feelz you could, well, this could be your hidden gem.

Congrats to Laura Shigihara, I expected less and was pleasantly surprised ! Although there is a few things about the story I'm not a big fan of, I loved the mood, and the music was wonderful.

Rakuen is easily my top favorite indie game. At first, I'd expected it to be lighthearted and wholesome game. 126478806.review:
I can't exactly remember how I first found this game, but I'm so glad I did. This might be one of the best hidden gems I have ever played.

Imagine if your favorite childhood book was in fact real and can be accessed through that door over there. That's exactly what happens in Rakuen. The boy's favorite book, read to him every night by his mom, is real and can be accessed from his hospital room. There, the world is lively and colorful, which contrasts the drab environment of the hospital. It's what any child could wish for.

The boy seeks out Morizora, the keeper of the forest, so he can be granted one wish. However, before his wish can be granted, he has to complete a series of tasks. This is where the gameplay gets most interesting. This world directly parallels the hospital, and the characters in the world directly parallel the patients, guests, and staff in the hospital. What happens in one world will impact the other.

Learning about the hospital patients is critical to completing the tasks at hand. At first glance, the hospital patients seem cold and distant. After all, they're in the hospital, which isn't the most cheerful of places. However, a first impression isn't everything. The late Anthony Bourdain once said "If I'm an advocate for anything, it's to move. As far as you can, as much as you can. Across the ocean, or simply across the river. Walk in someone else's shoes or at least eat their food. It's a plus for everybody." It is in learning about the patients where the gameplay gets most critical. I got to walk a mile in their shoes by exploring their backstories, complete with wholesome moments, heartwrenching experiences, and everything in between. I connected with them in unexpected ways and felt sympathy for them. At the end of the day, they and I felt more satisfied and fulfilled than before.

At the same time, the game doesn't hold back from touching upon sensitive subjects. Racism, feuding, guilt, insanity, and bullying are all addressed in the game. Even in a paradise such as Morizora's forest, the worst of human nature is still prevalent. However, even in the worst of moments did I still get to see the best in the characters. In parallel to the real world, sure human nature can be ugly, but it can be beautiful as well. The game certainly presents that well.

I would like to thank Laura Shigihara for making this game possible. The way she developed the story, the characters, the world, the game mechanics, and the soundtrack all contributed to this gem called Rakuen. I will certainly remember this for years to come.

122863845.review:
What a beautiful masterpiece this game turned out to be!! As someone who enjoys games that are heavily plot based, I'm so glad I played this game. It explores heartfelt themes such as love, friendship and family and sends you on an emotional ride that's very easy to get invested in. 

I think it's important to note that there may be some themes that are triggering for some people such as terminal illnesses, death and natural disasters. These themes do become fairly predominant throughout the game and are explored in a fairly light-hearted manner but just something to bear in mind.

Being an RPGmaker game, it was an easy game to manoeuvre but it was also very beautiful to look at in terms of scenery and art style. It does sometimes fluctuate from being a very relaxing, casual play to suddenly becoming quite unsettling. I usually don't enjoy that feeling however, it added so much depth to this game that I just can't be mad at the creepy parts. I also really loved the random little side quests you would stumble upon like the mushrooms and the sign posts. It just added to the cute appeal of the game. 

Finally, I cannot write a review about this game without touching on how beaaauutiful the music was. Props to the composers of the music and the voices who were featured. It really was the ribbon that wrapped this into a beautiful experience. I have met a couple of people who are absolute fans of this game and I really wish Rakuen was talked about more. It deserves to go down as a classic and I hope it continues to touch more hearts.

121702960.review:
It's a lovely game! I'm happy I purchased it and finally got to play it. Once I started I couldn't put it down for long. I was able to do all of the achievements without much trouble after thinking a little bit. I resorted to a guide twice to complete puzzles that weren't really hard but I was being too obtuse then. 

 It's a very emotional story that definitely made me cry more than once. The puzzles are really nice and nothing feels dragged too long. There's a change of pace about halfway through the game where it turns more into a cinematic/musical experience and less about actual gameplay. I didn't hate that per se because the narrative elements were still good and the emotional upbeats got higher, but I could also understand it if some players wouldn't find that change troublesome. The story is a 9/10 for me, simply because there are so many characters that are relevant and you only control less than a third of them and the ones that you do, aside for the main character, feel kind of arbitrary all things considered. I think that fact complicated the storytelling unnecessarily: either we should have been able to play with everyone or just let us control the main character until the end. Considering the ending the latter would have made more sense for me. 

 It's more than worth its full price. I thoroughly recommend it to anyone. It can be a lovely experience for a week without rushing it or a weekend if you are really into it.

Open the book called Rakuen, look into it's pages and find engrossing and quirky characters, and a carefully constructed world of love and tragedy.  Fall into the music, form bonds those around you, explore as much as you can and fling yourself headlong into the experience until you reach the final page and then sit, stunned, wishing for more.

This is a game for those who love stories, who want to be taken on a journey and discover the world set before them a piece at a time, and see where the narrative is going to go. There's gameplay, exploration, collecting, and interacting to do, but one way or the other the story will be told. 

Sail to paradise, behold Rakuen - play this game.

118439808.review:
The story lines are kind of cool albeit kind of saccharine and the art style is really pretty and fun. The worlds are quite engagingly built with nice variation and cool character design. I think this is a better game for kids/teen audiences or casual gamers though, since the puzzles themselves are extremely easy to solve, so maybe not all that engaging for gamers. There aren't many real secrets to be discovered since the game play is a tad bit too straightforward, but I like the moving between places once it gets going. 

I am also not partial to quite the amount of text based dialogue as this game had especially towards the end. With no other job for the player for many minutes but tapping enter and reading is not really my thing, I prefer games to be more interactive all of the time.

I found the repetition of the vocal song(s it sounded like the same song but im not sure) in the game really WAY too cheesy for me and wished there was a way to skip the singing parts which were really unnecessary and boring. They kind of took me out of the game and had me rolling my eyes and pressing mute every time, especially since it happened more and more in the end, like every 10 minutes. It got annoying instead of eliciting an emotional response. The actual background music in the game was always great and varied though. 

Perhaps too much influence from games like Undertale made the ending feel way too familiar and not all that creative or up to the actual game play leading up to it. But all in all it was a pretty positive experience regardless of these minor things and I ended up playing it through in a couple of days. Recommended when in the mood for something fairly cute and easy to play through in a few days.

115390830.review: Upfront, it’s actually been a while since I played this one. But when a few days ago I finally bought the soundtrack, aw man, no kidding, listening to those tunes just kind of stirred up a few lost emotions in me again. So I’m meanwhile feeling heavily obliged to give at least a positive rating here, even if just for the record. I know, everything already has been said in other reviews, so to make it short, definitely one of the best RPGMaker games out there, on par with To the Moon and such classic top titles. Highly emotional, brilliant storytelling, good length (though as a general warning, also a bit melancholic because it’s dealing a LOT with loss and hope). And what’s more (as mentioned above), it even features an awesome soundtrack including vocal tracks that reminds you a lot of classic JRPGs like FF. Just don’t expect too complex gameplay (like some other reviews criticized), this one is of course again all for the journey, but that’s actually good in my opinion ;) Enough said. If you like soul-touching, unconventional games just try it out, sale prices are low for the price-sensitive people, so all in all I can’t really think of anything that speaks against this precious hidden gem. Definitely two thumbs up from me! :)

115331942.review:
So it took me 5 years to finally play this.  I'd heard about it back in '16 or '17 when it was still in development, but I didn't even have a Steam account back then.  I heard that supershigi was looking for people to stream it during the 5th anniversary week (May 5-12, '22), so I went ahead and bought the game.  Now this is not a game designed for people looking for ultramodern 3D graphics, or a game designed for people looking for combat, or anything like that.  This is a game that explores a story of loss, of grief, and making the best of what would otherwise be a terrible situation.  You will cry when you play this...I don't care what kind of stone or metal you claim your heart is made of, you will shed tears, and you'll be grateful for shedding every last tear.  I've played full many NES-, SNES-, and PS1-era RPGs, and this one (despite its complete lack of a combat system, extremely unusual for an RPG, though this falls a bit more towards a sort of playable visual novel) stacks up VERY well with the VERY best of them.

Story:  10/10 - Without spoiling too much, it's a beautifully well-written story.  You play mostly as a boy (named Boy, no relation to Kratos) who is in a hospital in Sendai.  This hospital is dealing with the fallout from the Great Tohoku Earthquake, its associated tsunami, and the Fukushima nuclear plant disaster (though these aren't listed by name, it's rather easy to put two and two together based on certain in-game elements).  The story is broken up into 5 chapters, each one dealing with a different character, and centers around a book called Rakuen, that details a fantasy forest, but is a sort of reflection of the real world.

Gameplay:  9.5/10 - It's an RPG without one of the most critical elements of an RPG...a combat system.  While a good bit of the game is fairly linear in design, there are some sidequests and other side content that can easily be overlooked...it would take a very astute and thorough player to find absolutely everything the first time through, though it can be done.

Graphics/sound:  10/10 - The artwork is fantastic...Emmy Toyonaga and crew did an exceptional job with the various sprites and storyboard character designs.  The music...if you've never heard of Laura Shigihara before, look her up on YouTube...she's been on there for more than 10 years, and has been making music for close to 20.  The music she put together for Rakuen is among her very best.  I couldn't help but try to sing along on various parts.

Fun factor:  10/10 - I found the game to be rather heavy on its theme, but some parts of the game aren't meant to be taken seriously.  These parts of the game really shine through, and serve as a welcome foil to the sadder parts of the story.

Overall:  10/10 - As I said, this game will make you cry.  A lot.  And you'll be happy you did.   This is a game for people that have experienced loss, and the grief coming from it, and serves as a reminder that we really are all in this together, no matter our backgrounds, no matter what we believe, and that there are certain ways we can understand each other and help each other heal through sharing these things.

115330270.review:
An absolutely beautiful game, which I won't go into depth explaining here but I will leave a few points to note:

1. Music is central to the game, particularly the handful of songs that include vocals which add emotional punch to the game. I found myself pulling out my guitar and trying to play a long with a few tracks, namely Morizora's Cave. 
2. While this game is beautiful... it is very sad. It by no means has a bleak outlook, but it is undoubtedly a sad game... That's just a word of warning.
3. Game is short (took me <8 hours) and all the actions you take feel very logical and straightforward. However, you move at a fairly slow walking speed and you cannot run so it can at times feel like your on a massive virtual hike.
4. The art is cute but quite straightforward when compared to similar titles, however, the game more than makes up for this with the soundtrack so it was no problem for me.  

With that stuff listed I'll finish with a little tidbit of self reflection no one asked for:
Emotional games have, in the past, made me choke up or perhaps shed a single or a few tears, but as it happens it's usually a fairly controlled situation... The last 5 or so minutes of this game made me CRY, not choke up, not shed a tear or two... I was on the brink of bawling my eyes out. This game hit me in a very personal place, and it felt very earned. Without spoiling anything or giving too much personal information all I can say is: 

I can do nothing but recommend this game. If you are looking for an emotional title, this is it.

115326194.review:
Rakuen broke me at multiple parts, and the only thing that kept me from absolutely sobbing by the end of it was the fact that there were other people in the room at the time when I finished it (because I promise you the tears were blinding me by that point).

I was first skeptical about the game when the beginning seemed to go on for a long time without leaving the hospital, and then once more when I found out this game wouldn't have any combat elements, but all of those concerns were meaningless once I started to explore the world and the stories of the characters. Meeting the other residents at the hospital, and then learning all of their backstories... Let's just say this game will give you MAJOR FEELS.

My only complaint (which is partially my fault anyway) is that I missed a SINGLE collectible pet in an area I was not able to return to, which barred me from two achievements that I'll most likely play through again to get (because the story is worth it). I was pretty good at observing every object and corner of the map, so that ended up being the only thing I didn't collect. That being said, there is enough flavor text and lore-filled reading material to make even searching the world rewarding.

If you want to play a story-rich, combat-free adventure with amazing fantasy elements and well-written dialogue, you owe it to yourself to play this game!

115322672.review:
This game feels more like a journey - a heartbreakingly painful yet wholesome one; just like life itself. I might revisit "Rakuen" in the (near) future, but for now the tears have been shed and I keep inside my heart this precious little world and these words: "Life is strange, isn't it? When you feel like you can't go on, the most random things can remind you that you need to have hope. We never know what's going to happen." 

I hope anyone reading this might feel inclined to embark on this special voyage and allow this story to break and mend you at the same time. Rather than offering some well-thought out review, I think it's best to just allow the game to show you what it's got in store for you. I wish you all the best and I hope you all know: You've all got more strength in you than you might know.

A story beautifully told. Make no mistake, if you're gonna play this game, you're gonna play it for the story.
The gameplay is pretty simple and includes walking around, talking to characters and solving puzzles (most of which are quite easy). You might also find the game somewhat slow in the beginning - don't worry, it gets better.
The story is a bitter-sweet emotional roller coaster with great use of symbolism, metaphor and foreshadowing. 
The world built with beautiful pixel art is inhabited by a cast of unique characters who offer some weird and funny dialogue.
And a special shout-out to the soundtrack, which is very good indeed (this game's developer's first breakthrough was writing the soundtrack for Plants vs Zombies, she knows what she's doing).

As someone who isn’t into indie story driven games, or someone who even feels compelled enough to make reviews… I believe Rakuen is a masterpiece in every sense of the word!

Very beautiful art and sprite work. Everything was just so aesthetically pleasing I couldn’t keep my eyes off for even a second! I even loved the little facial expressions and movements each character made. It really helped make the world feel alive.

Gameplay was simple but VERY effective. It was very straightforward, but the little puzzles where very interactive and fun to solve so it didn’t simply feel like a cutscene just to get to the next plot line. It was such a cool idea, too, swapping between two worlds that were connected to each other, it complimented the experience so well!

This was some of THE BEST storytelling I’ve ever seen. Throughout the game the dialogue is engaging and interesting making me want to learn more about all these characters. I loved the little environmental details scattered throughout the real world and how interconnected everything was with the plot. The story itself was truly phenomenal and heartwarming with a fantastic blend of heartbreak and horror elements.

Lastly, the music. THE MUSIC!!! OH MY GOD THE MUSIC!!! EVERY. SINGLE. ONE. They’re all like candy to my ears. Nice and sweet. The ones with lyrics have beautiful vocals and messages of encouragement or endearment and I just love all of them!

From the bottom of my heart, THANK YOU to everyone who helped make this game! I had such a great experience! This was probably the best 13 hours I’ve spent in a long while and the best $19 I’ve spent buying the collector’s edition. (Sue is my favorite character btw, I just adore how she goes on and on about her tiny planets, such a big imagination!)

I’ve also recently started exploring Ms. Shigihara’s works which is how I came across this game and I just keep getting surprise after surprise! WHAT AN UNDERRATED ARTIST!!! I know I’m gonna be a proud supporter for a very long time!

113197731.review:
My feelings for this game are complicated. Mostly because of how much I love the character of Sue, her story is amazing and very well written.

Sadly I can't say the same for the rest of the game.

The game play of Gakuen involves you checking every object in a room to find a key which you use to unlock a door. And behind that door is another room where you will check more objects, sometimes you need to pull a lever.

I would find myself wandering a building for 15 minutes checking every object over and over until I found the one I missed, it was extremely tedious.

Perhaps if the story was great it would make up for the bad gameplay, but sadly that is not the case. 

I think the story is you helping the fantasy alter egos of hospital patients and that will somehow help them in the real world, but if that is the case you never see it. No one in the hospital is ever changed by your actions in any obvious way. 

I made the whole story feel empty to me, I didn’t understand why I was doing all these lame “puzzles” if it wasn’t helping anyone.

The only thing that kept me going was Sue, whenever I found one of her marbles I went to see her as soon as possible. That song Build a Little World With Me nearly brought a tear to my eye.

Which is why my feelings are complicated. Is Sue worth baring through everything else?

And my conclusion is no, it isn’t. Instead play To the Moon.

113137343.review:
Often, I find a story, whether in written, animated or programmed format, where I can easily tell what is going to happen. This here game is one of those cases. I got it right for most of the characters' individual tales ('scept Tony and Uma, those two hid the twists of their tales rather well). That is a simple thing to do after more than two decades of reading books, watching anime and playing games. And just looking a the art of the Boy and his Mom together makes it obvious to me what kind of story I'm getting into when I play it.

Now, while it may sound like I'm complaining, that is certainly not the case. Just because I know with a high level of certainty what is to happen in a tale, that does not mean I will do the uncouth thing of saying "meh, I've seen in already, I'll pass". No Sir!

You see, Rakuen is not a tale that is asking you to be shocked, or awed, or surprised, or thrilled, or elated, or any other of those things we gamers seek on our RPGs, J or otherwise. This is, after all, a tale of inevitabilities. A tale of “seizing the moment”. A tale about the simple, often mundane and common things that weight us down and lift our spirits, seen from the eyes of a child.

I’m honestly impressed at the seamless way in which Laura Shigahara and her team put together the fantastic and realistic side of the kind of tales we know by heart because they are so common, so everyday as the fight against sickness, guilt, aging, loneliness and fear. How they elevated all that from common to inspiring. And all with that gorgeous OST, complete with thematic songs for each of its mayor chapters… Simply beautiful.

Rauken has earned a place among those honest, simple games that are not about great things, but about the little things often forgotten in the shadow of more flashy, epic tales. Together with OneShot, Journey, Gris, and the like.

This is a game that the more hardcore will let pass for obvious reasons. But this is the kind of tale that, to those who found it, like one of those lil’ doors that pop around in Rakuen’s world, will lead to a memorable experience.

Think whatever you will about non-violent games like this, but keep them in mind. Who knows? Maybe one day you will find one of them at the right time, and they will mean something for you. Happy gaming, and don’t forget to bring tissues with you. You’ll need them.

111880990.review:
Rakuen is a story about a boy in a hospital who uses a magic book to help make the lives of the other patients he resides with just a little bit better. The music is beautiful, the art (especially the character art) is really solid, and the story... is interesting. 

In Rakuen you're tasked with traveling to a fantasy world (of sorts) in which you help the fantasy counterparts of the real world overcome certain personal issues. The stories surrounding the patients are reasonably well-crafted, and can definitely get a little raw at parts. The themes tackled are pretty heavy, given the hospital setting in the real world, so expect to see lots of themes of isolation, grief, despair, parental abandonment, and even racism. At the conclusion of each story, one of the characters sings a heartfelt song, and the player moves on to their next task. There's plenty of entertaining gameplay to break up the crushing emotional weight of the small stories, although if you're not familiar with RPGmaker games you might not be a fan of the constant backtracking and fetch quests. 

I think Rakuen does a good job of creating an emotional tale, but where it really struggles is in maintaining a good pace. At the end of the short stories, after you've completed your song and gotten what you needed, the characters in that story are essentially cured of whatever was afflicting them. It's such a wild 180 from the major themes of loss and grief that are present in Rakuen. It's like the game is saying "here's an emotionally devastating tale about how someone's mental illness has torn a family apart but they've learned to accept it, now let's magically cure that illness and get a happy ending!" Especially given the ending of the main storyline in Rakuen, the fairytale endings of these sidequests feels a little tone deaf, to be frank. 

Speaking of the main storyline, Rakuen's main storyline frequently gets drowned out by the side stories present in the game. These side stories do advance the game's plot, but during the last 10-20 minutes of the game it really seems like the developers just ran out of time to develop the main story and rushed things straight to the conclusion. It's not a bad ending by any means, but the game suddenly seems in a hurry to wrap things up, and in my opinion it lessens the emotional impact of a game that is designed to create an emotionally impactful story. 

The music, art, gameplay and level design of Rakuen are fantastic, and the story itself is unique and emotional. I only wish that it took the time to stay consistent.

111853254.review:
I like the music and graphics, but the gameplay is just garbage. The game boasts "eerie room escape puzzles" but are they really puzzles if you can just mash the space bar to interact with everything in the room and eventually win? The biggest challenge is trying not to get bored slowly walking between rooms. Not to mention the gameplay doesn't supplement the story in any meaningful way; in fact these disconnected puzzle rooms often work against the story because they throw off the pacing. Usually by the time the gameplay segments were over, I'd forgotten where I was even headed in the first place. It honestly feels like they created the walking sim part of the game first, then figured it's too short so they decreased the character speed to that of a snail, and added these dumb interactive "puzzle" elements where you have to trade an item that NPC A gives you with NPC B who is a solid 5 minute walk away on the other side of the dungeon. 

So anyways, maybe the story is good, maybe it's not, I dunno, I dropped this game somewhere around when I went into the dream world and got to the first story which was basically just a "racism is le BAD!" animal allegory for all of 30 seconds before more tedious gameplay was shoved in my face. Yeah, thanks but no thanks. If this is the caliber of stories present in this anthology, I think I'll pass on the rest. I wish one day a story would surprise me and tell me about how racism saved their lives; at least it would be somewhat original. Oh and because this is an RPG maker game, of course le spooky stuff has to randomly happen with no rhyme or reason, which the game never comments on. Anyways this game just got really tiring so I dropped it halfway.

106559736.review:
I have mixed feelings about this game. The good:

1) The puzzles are easy enough that I can figure them out reasonably quickly without cheats while still being engaging.
2) The art is good. In particular, the character design is fun.
3) The sound design and ambient music are good (except when you're moving from area to area quickly--then the music changes are a little jarring).

The less good:
1) Particularly on the 'other side,' several of the puzzles are things you complete by wandering back and forth. They take longer because of the travel time, not because they're difficult. I'm not a fan of that.
2) The game is short and doesn't have much replayability; once you've completed it, it's done. I had it open while I wasn't playing sometimes.. I'd say realtime it took me about twelve hours to complete.
3) Ultimately, rather than feeling like the game was being real with me, I felt like it was using tearjerker topics in a kind of manipulative way. I'm not saying there was no real feeling in there (there was), but it was a little over the top in what it chose to portray while also being perplexing in how some things were shown (I'm not going to say which because I don't want to spoil anything).

105425570.review:
When my girlfriend (now wife) and I were long distance (in UK and USA), we played this together over screen-sharing.  It was a perfect game for playing over an internet connection with some lag since it generally didn't require fast reflexes and you usually couldn't die, and was an emotional, mysterious story (though historical elements of it gradually became clear without the game spelling every detail out to you) that we found great for playing together as a couple.

My only complaint is that sometimes, (like, twice in the game that I remember) you were suddenly dropped into a situation where you had to act quickly or die.  If it were an action game then that would be expected, but this was for the most part a relaxing story driven game, so these sudden stressful parts were unwanted - if you wanted that type of challenge you'd play a different game.  They don't last long (maybe a minute), but it's still a shame they are there, otherwise I could recommend this game to total non-gamers who just want a story and some puzzles.

104854650.review:
I tried hard to get into this game. After playing through all the To The Moon games and loving them, I really wanted to give this game a chance. But while the art and music are really great (so great I even bought the soundtack), the gameplay and story unfortunately aren't quite doing it for me.

The gameplay feels really sluggish for me with tons of backtracking. You slowly (without a run feature) walk to point A, flick switch B, go to point C, go to the now opened door, pick up item D, go back to point A, flick switch B back & flick switch E instead, so you can enter room F and use item D there. Rinse and repeat throughout the whole game.

Occasionally you get a little cutscene thrown in that expains more of the story, but with how far apart these cutscenes sometimes are (in between all the tedious puzzles and walking around), it didn't manage to really hold my attention. Plus the characters felt too cliche and forced for me and the story way too predictable. It's really bad when I can already tell exactly where the story is going long before the relevant cutscene that shows sad event happening in a way that tries too hard to tuck at the players heartstrings.

I don't know, compared to To The Moons more subtle story writing this feels too on the nose for me.

Oh God, where do I even begin... First of all, you NEED to play this game.
But seriously, just when you think the story is getting a little happier, BAM, the waterworks start again. Such an emotional rollercoaster of a game but SO worth it.

From the beginning, I had a feeling I knew which direction the story was going to take but I didn't expect so MANY feels throughout the whole game. I am SO glad that I chose to play though because, though a lot of the story is heartbreaking and deals with a range of sensitive topics, it's carried extremely well through the storytelling.  Not just one story, but several combined and tied into the overall story, surrounding one little boy.

I sincerely hope that anyone who finds this game and is on the fence about buying or playing it, sees this review and goes for it.  It really is quite a sad story but is also very charming and thoughtful too.

On a side note; I studied Japanese language at university, so there were a few small bits included in the story that I picked up on that I thought were a really nice little touch. Really liked the folklore/cultural references.

Thank you for creating such a heartbreaking yet charming game. It was a pleasure to play through.

It is, ultimately, a game full of emotions, and many sad ones at that, but it's well-worth at least one playthrough, if not more. I will play this again (I'm missing 3 achievements!) 

One thing I didn't care for is that there is a fatphobic storyline (Monsieur Bud) and a little piece of a storyline that mocks people who struggle with hygiene and tidiness (one of the onions). I would love to have seen these omitted from the game or handled differently.

100695434.review:
Can't believe the game did this to me.  Didn't know what to expect and didn't believe other reviews, but I'll reinforce the remarks on this game.

Getting the quick stuff out of the way.  The graphics are good, portraits and tile-sets mainly, a couple human character sprites could have been more distinct and/or expressive, as it would take me a second or two to recall who someone was when seen outside their usual location.  Controls are acceptable and quite simple.  I switched between keyboard and mouse, the mouse lets you click things to see if they’re interactable before you traverse the room, the keyboard only required 2 keys aside from arrow keys.  The only complaint would be the lack of running which makes exploration tedious and pads playtime by an hour or two.  There is a sprint patch, but that unbalances some areas that shouldn't allow sprinting, it would have been better had the game integrated it so it could be controlled when appropriate.

Now the reasons to play the game; music is great, if I were to knock anything is since the designer and musician were one in the same, the game appears like it was first and foremost a music portfolio piece, as the music in certain places don't match the scene completely.  It's as if the development was mentally divided, or the music was made first, then the best fit track was placed where required.  I came to like the track "These Grey Walls" which you will hear often, but the area it plays on doesn't fit the mood initially.

The story and characters were predictable, unless they were not; weird I know, but due to tropes, heavy foreshadowing, or some thought, a lot of stuff was no surprise.  I did miss the mark on a few things, so it wasn't 100% transparent.  In terms of dividing the story into chapters, they get shorter over time, as if there was a rush to finish the game off before the motivation ran out.  Lengthening later story arcs would have lessened the impact of the story, instead cutting drawn-out content in exchange for more time spent delving into characters before the primary objectives would have benefited.  Getting into content, gameplay elements also start giving way to story, making the first half and later half feel different.

Only a few characters really get development, some don’t matter after 15 minutes.  I have seen someone unaware one character had minor development after their arc, which is easy to miss due to not expecting anything more.  More time spent fleshing out some background characters, and getting to interact with critical characters more would have helped out; perhaps even removing the focus being on one character at a time.  Speaking of background characters, one character briefly mentioned at the beginning isn't shown until far later, some scenes spent building up that character would have clarified the ending just a bit more.  This is perhaps part of that rushing to finish, there is no side story to distract or remind you, or developed from beginning to end linearly without a solid plan to reinforce the background.

Despite the weaknesses, it is a greatly written game.  The world building is top notch and design is fantastic,  Some things are unclear and were purposefully left vague by developer admission.  I’m writing this review because it flew under my radar for years and doesn’t deserve to be missed.

99991469.review:
Rakuen is a bittersweet story based game. The gameplay is mostly fetch quests, talking, and simple puzzles.

The early game is slow in terms of the plot and the dialogue is a bit weak. Fortunately both get better around 2-3 hours in. The stories are the best part, predictable in some areas, unpredictable in others. It's imaginative and goes back and forth between reality/fantasy. Characters are mostly decent. There are a few you'll be invested in and a few who you won't really care much about. The dialogue isn't anything special, but it doesn't detract from the story. Unfortunately, there's other stuff that does detract from the game.

To start with, the game is way longer than it should be. It's a 4-7 hour game that takes around 10 hours. It never gets tiresome, but it drags at times and outstays its welcome.

I mentioned the stories as a positive, but they're also a negative as well. The stories within simply don't make much sense when examined which leads to a bunch of plot holes. These plot holes are basically ignored by the creator and simply left to you to use your imagination. My job isn't to fill in holes in your story, that was your job. The plot holes aren't a huge deal based on what this is going for, but repeated plot holes are a result of poor writing.

The gameplay is mostly lackluster. It could be ignored if there wasn't so much of it, but there's a lot of it. Walk around at a really slow pace talking to people, checking a whole lot of objects, and collecting stuff for fetch quests. There's a lot of backtracking as well, which means you get to plod along the same areas over and over and over. There are a few puzzles but they're mostly very simple. The game almost always tells you the answer to the puzzles anyways as though the game was designed for the mentally retarded. If you get stumped on them, it might be a good sign you have some brain damage.

Rakuen is an above average game due to its story elements. The length, plot holes, and gameplay elements keep it from being better than that though. A few fixes, especially the ability to run, would've gone a long way to making the overall experience more palatable.

A quote from part of another review about this game that made me laugh since I did it: “If you want, you can take a perverse pleasure in lifting up toilet seat lids and filling up sinks and leaving them like that. Pretty monstrous behavior” -Seranth

97492854.review:
[i]Rakuen[/i] (Japanese: 楽園, ‘paradise’) is a hospitalised boy's handling of the cards he is dealt in life. The hospital becomes his new home, its dwellers his new neighbours.

The game is a bit of an oddball. It feels as though it mixes new and old technology. It could very well be a limitation of its engine, RPG Maker XP, but I'm not familiar with it and cannot say. The resolution is fairly low and 4:3, and it has to be played fullscreen. Perhaps due to this, it is not possible to see the Steam overlay, nor achievement pop-ups, while playing. These things did not bother me, however. I didn't even notice the lower resolution until I looked at screenshots I'd taken from the game (these are not stretched, after all, unlike the game window).

Rakuen is fraught with symbolism and fantastic elements, making it very enjoyable on more levels than one. It's not only thrilling to explore the boy's mind and fantasies, but to also discover all the symbolism throughout the game and how thorough it is. It is a game that gives you lots to think about, which makes it all the more enjoyable to play it through. Knowing a bit of Japanese and/or about Japanese culture and history adds another layer to the enjoyment of the game. Character names and the like take on another meaning with this knowledge, like the first character you meet, Yami, meaning [i]darkness[/i], or the song you are piecing together, Mori no Kokoro, meaning [i]heart of the forest[/i]. The same goes with signs and the like that you can see in-game.

The music is memorable, the art gorgeous, the characters likable, the world building well done and sufficient enough to arouse one's curiosity, and although narratively, the game offers little new, it is still well crafted to the point that getting invested in and enjoying the story and its characters is relatively easy.

If I were to give a tip for a first-time playthrough: pay attention to people's names.

[b]Verdict:[/b] 7+/10

96372803.review:
Powerful experience, get ready for waterworks if you're sensitive to sad media. Make no mistake, while there are definitely a solid number of happy moments, and even parts that may make you laugh a bit, this narrative will test your ability to handle tragedy many times over, and it won't let you off the ride once it starts.

That said, I still recommend this game. Yeah, yeah, it's an RPG Maker game, and the gameplay style itself might be tired, but Laura Shigihara works with what she has and does something wonderful with it. The graphics are beautiful, the story is well put-together, the puzzles are thought-provoking without being too difficult, and the characters are memorable, even after you've completed the game.

I will say, the vocals are a little jarring at first, as they aren't frequent and they mostly take the form of song. Stick with it until the end though, and you'll see why Shigihara has decided to go for the occasional audible parts. The payoff is definitely worth it.

Oh, and if you buy it, one spoiler-free tip for you: explore everything, and if you find a sidequest-type item, drop what you're doing and follow through with it. And always follow through with the ending of a main quest before starting the next part. I didn't do that with one aspect of the game and I am kicking myself for it.

SPOILERS AHEAD: When I say what I do for the tip, what I mean is [spoiler] check on the girl with the marbles frequently, and do so especially right after you've finished her quest, the one with the dog. DON'T GO TO THE FESTIVAL UNTIL YOU HAVE FOLLOWED UP WITH HER. I didn't, so when I went to give her the marble soda bottle, I was crushed. That made the game almost too hard to finish, but I'm glad I did it.[/spoiler]

It's simply an amazing experience with remarkable characters, clever puzzles and beautiful soundtrack, it's warm and entertaining. I think I will remember this one for a long time. 10/10 recommended, guaranteed to make you cry.

94708580.review:
I feel confident recommending Rakuen for anyone who's interested in more narrative than game, someone who values a story over an experience. Fans of Freebird Games will feel right at home with its quirky writing, endearing characters and charming music (of which I will complain, briefly, below). The sum of these parts forms an incredibly hopeful, awfully depressing tale about love and loss. If this sounds like your idea of a fun time (or maybe you just enjoy crying, I can get behind that), then I'd encourage you to pick it up and have a go at it. You will not be disappointed.

Unfortunately, the game is not without its faults. None of these are deal breakers and, honestly, most of my complaints are very minor. What's more, they likely will only resonate with those who have previously played the game, but nevertheless I feel I must relate them here on the off chance that Super Shigi herself reads these and wants to make better on game number two. Proceed at your own risk any potential future players, lest ye be spoiled:
[list]
[*]Sometimes, the music doesn't land. Specifically, most of the times that a song [spoiler]with lyrics[/spoiler] began, it almost immediately took me out of the game. The first time it happened, [spoiler]it caught me so off-guard that I believe I audibly laughed. I went from a somber sadness to laughter immediately.[/spoiler] It actually got to the point where I was not sure if this was intentional or not - without these moments of reprieve, the full weight of emotional impact would surely have crippled me. I think the main issue is that these particular tracks are never subtly placed in with the rest of the score - they're always brought front and center. You can immediately tell when one of these songs is coming up because, well, it's almost announced in how the audio is mixed. (The exceptions being [spoiler]Sue's song about building worlds together, which is subtly brought in as part of what amounts to a cinematic, and Mom's song to Yami at the end of the game [i]prior[/i] to having the rest of the cast chime in.[/spoiler])
[*]The story doesn't give itself time to breathe. Specifically, there are many story beats that had more time been given to the player to sit and reflect on the magnitude of what was happening, a truly deep and heartfelt sadness would have taken hold and been difficult to shake. To me, the most prominent and unfortunate of such moments was [spoiler]with the Alzheimer's sufferer and his saddened wife. The excellent scene of them holding one another in the field of flowers that he had planted for reasons unknown to his deteriorating mind is sweet and hopeful, tinged with a sadness that comes from the sheer relatability and reality of it.[/spoiler] Instead of sitting in that moment, though, the game quickly whisks you away to the next flight of whimsy. It doesn't really feel rushed so much as it feels excited to show you the next grand/sad thing. This could be to reflect the perspective of the main character (youth [i]is[/i] hasty, after all), or it could be, as I supposed in my earlier point, to spare the player the burden of an overwhelming sadness.
[/list]

There are other complaints to be made about the more game-y portions of Rakuen - the poor menuing springs to mind immediately - but that's so very obviously not what the game is about that it feels unfair to call attention or make note of them...so I won't do so here. The game's pros far outweigh the cons, and literally every other consideration of narrative, presentation and music I would champion as masterclass - with the exception of the two above points. 

Ultimately, Rakuen is a great gem of grief, a diamond of depression, and a nuanced narrative. It's masterfully crafted and well-told besides. A fantastic first effort by Laura Shigihara and a well-spun yarn, this is an easy purchase for any fan of narrative video gaming.

[i]Not a fan of RPGMaker. At all. However, it allows many indie developers to tell a good story. It's important to clearly understand this part: it's either about the story or it makes no sense, because... Well, what kind of gameplay can there be? Unless you're a fan of the genre.

Nevertheless, it is a very heart-warming project by a locally known sound designer, in some ways even personal. Bittersweet experience.[/i]

Cuando compré Rakuen, la verdad, es que no esperaba mucho. Estaba barato y un par de comentarios positivos me llevó a comprarlo. Fue de las mejores decisiones que tomé en este año. 
El juego es increíble. 
El juego tiene una duración de entre 5-7 horas, dependiendo que tan bien lleves el resolver algunos puzzles. Vale aclarar que estos no son tan complicados, pero alguno que otro puede marearte si no te exploras y te lees todo lo leíble. La banda sonora es un 8, por lo menos. Está muy bien preparado para llevarte en el clímax de lo que se supone estás viviendo, pero hay momentos también que puede haber mucho silencio. Supongo que eso estará hecho para incomodar o ponerte nervioso, pero le faltaría algún detalle como "sonido de pasos" en estos momentos. De todas formas, todo está excelentemente logrado.
Si esperas una jugabilidad alta, este no es tu juego. El juego es sencillo. Flechitas, y 2 o 3 botones más, pero mayormente solo usaras 1. 
Ahora bien, en lo que historia respecta, ahí es donde más brilla el juego. Tendrá momentos divertidos, momentos de tensión y momentos sumamente tristes (jueguenlo con algún pañuelito cerca). 
Recomiendo este juego 100% para jugar al menos, una vez en la vida.

93489898.review:
[h1] Rakuen [/h1]

[b] An Emotional Tale of Love And Innocence [/b]

[b] Rakuen [/b] is a RPG Maker title that contains a deeply emotional plot, some wonderful and colorful characters, and fantastic art and music. It is a game that took me a few years to actually finish and appreciate, and is a game that has contributed to my newfound respect for games built in a similar way to many RPG Maker titles. In the past, I have tended to find these game a bit dull and generic, with simplistic stories that tend to tug at the heartstrings or focus on pure horror and puzzles that are either braindead simple or smothered in moon logic. Thankfully, [b] Rakuen [/b] breaks through these conventions not only to bring forth a great video game, but for many this might be one of the best titles of its genre ever made.

I'll start by going over the visuals, music, and sound, since it is what you will encounter first. The visuals in this game are stunning, with colorful environments and detailed, original characters everywhere you travel. It feels as if nearly no color is left underrepresented, and various lights and darks are showcased in impressive fashion. The stunning art is paired quite well with a great soundtrack and some quirky sound design. The music fits many situations and amplifies the personality of every location and character that you encounter. The sound design fits well here as well, with various bumps, sound effects, and short melodies adding richness to each encounter and dialogue interaction. It is truly a great mix of art and sound design, with only one flaw that I personally have - the theme songs that play throughout the campaign. These songs were structured well and made great sense with the overall plot, but I just felt they were a bit too "cheesy" at times for me to fully enjoy them. Each voice actor has a bit too much crispness in their singing, and it feels a bit "off" when listening to it. I may be in the minority here, but I felt it reduced the impact that some of the songs were aiming to make on the player. Still, besides this minor flaw, [b] Rakuen [/b] shines on an appearance and auditory level. Yet how does it fare once you peek under the hood and listen a bit closer to its message?

The main selling point of this title is the story, and it is pretty damn good here. The plot revolves around a young boy needing to assist various characters around a hospital with their personal issues, all of which involve a mix of personal strife and medical complication. The boy's goal is to help everyone in order to get  chance to wake up and talk with a great and powerful forest god named Morizora, who will grant him a single wish upon his completion of his journey. The plot throws many original backstories and interactions at the player, and many bits and pieces of the main character, various side characters, and the world are introduced as you progress. There is a lot of emotion in this one, so have some tissues ready if you tend to react a bit more strongly to emotional titles. The plot wraps up pretty nice, but I also have an issue with a bit of the pacing. I felt that there could have been one less story out of the four or five you encounter, and it would have helped with the length and pacing of the game a lot more. I sank a bit over 12 hours into this one, and if it were to have ended around the 10 hour mark I would have had a bit less fatigue with the game as a whole. The plot is still great at the end of the day, and it is likely the primary reason you would play and enjoy this title.

Next up, gameplay. If I had to pick a part of the game to label the weakest, it would likely be the gameplay portions. The gameplay is by no means poor in any way - however, it could have used with some more interactivity, minigames, side quests, and puzzles to shake things up over time. The puzzles in this title were a bit less than what I was expecting, and they never ended up being too tricky besides the occasional one or two. Since most of the game is spent walking around and talking to characters, it also would have been nice to have some more minigames/activities to do during these encounters. The gameplay seems to show everything its got by the 3-4 hour mark, and while it never becomes horribly dull, I feel that they missed a huge opportunity here to add a bit more life to the title. This is the weakest aspect of [b] Rakuen [/b], and while traditional RPGMaker fans may not be bothered too much by this aspect of the title, other players may find it to become a bit repetitive.

As for other aspects of the game, I will cover them in this section. The UI is fairly simple and clean, with not too much involved from the jump. The lack of voice acting is a smart choice overall, though it does become a bit jarring to hear a character's voice in a song if you had never heard it in any other context beforehand (which may be the reason I was so put off by it from the start). The game is very theme-heavy, with each character representing a specific emotion, lifestyle, or character trait. Lastly, some background details may require the player to put two and two together, as it delivers information in a bit of an ambiguous yet intriguing fashion.

Overall, I found [b] Rakuen [/b] to be a delightful game. The story, characters, art, and music made it such an enjoyable experience to partake in, and I'll likely remember my run through the game for a long, long time. I played this title with my girlfriend, and it was a memorable way to bond, talk about complex topics, and get emotional together. The shortcomings in gameplay, some aspects of the music, and the overall length/pacing brought this title down a bit more than I expected, but I still thought the overall experience was something extremely valuable and artistic. I can easily [b] Recommend [/b] this title to those looking for an emotional story with some albeit simple gameplay, all wrapped up in an attractive visual and auditory package. [b] Rakuen [/b] is one of the best RPGMaker-style titles I have ever played, and one that should not go under the radar for fans of indie titles.

[h2] Final Verdict: 8/10 (Great) [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37542043-ADHD-Reviews/

Rakuen es un videojuego del genero de la aventura. Empezaremos nuestra historia, ingresado en un hospital,  en el cual, su madre le va a visitar todos los dias .A raiz de la lectura  un libro que se llama Rakuen,empezara nuestra historia.

Aspectos positivos: Traduccion al español,graficamente esta muy bien para ser un juego retro(destacando especialmente los escenarios externos al hospital),referencias a la cultura japonesa,las primeras horas te cuesta meterte en la historia,pero luego invita totalmente a pasarse el juego,su musica y como te acompaña en el juego es sencillamente superior,es un juego que te puede dar perfectamente para minimo 9 horas y alguna mas si quieres conseguir todo.Su historia tiene partes muy emotivas y sentimentales.

Aspectos negativos:no existe ningun tipo de configuracion en el menu(resolucion,volumen de sonido etc),nuestro personaje atraviesa algunos objetos(muy pocos),no se pueden hacer capturas del juego,existen logros y se desbloquean(pero no te saldra el salto automatico en la partida de que has conseguido ese logro)

Rakuen es un videojuego,que merece ser probado y que disfrutara aquella gente que le guste una buena historia,con sus puzzles y acertijos.Y mas recomendado en oferta

91665473.review:
Rakuen is a short, mechanically simple game. Games like these are not good because of their mechanics, but rather because of the plot and meaning conveyed throughout the experience. I truly believe that a game like Rakuen elevates the medium from entertainment to art -- not to say it couldn't be both. 

Between the writing, music, and imagery, this game will [i]change[/i] you, much like a good book or film. The themes of sickness, health, the bonds that tie friends and family, kindness, bravery, and closure are relevant to all of us in a deeply profound way. If you give this game a chance, I promise you won't be disappointed. 

[spoiler]You may cry.[/spoiler]

91665229.review:
I've just finished my first play-through of this game, and I already want to go back to the start so I can enjoy it all over again.

I'm a sucker for anything where real-life struggles are transposed into fantasy worlds, and this game absolutely ticked that box. It was so satisfying to help all the different characters, and see your work's impact in the real world, and I really loved that your mum was always there to offer help or advice - this was such a gentle and wholesome touch. The story never got too saccharine, and the spookiness of the Envoy was blended in perfectly alongside the story's triumphs. The puzzles were at just the right level to be stimulating without being annoying, and the music and art were simply beautiful. 

I would have liked the links between the real-world and the book-world to be more deeply explored (for example HOW is it that giving a ring to a Leeble means that their real-world equivalent is then wearing it?), but this is by no means a game-breaker. By and large, I'm happy to chalk it up to 'that's just part of the magic' and not pry into it too closely. 

All in all, a wonderful game with emotional punch, which really makes you think about what's important, and how precious your actions in the present can be. I heartily recommend it.

91624682.review:
Rakuen is a fairly short game; I was able to complete it and all of its achievements in about 6 hours. However, the number of times I cried while playing this game is in no way proportionate to the amount of time I spent playing. Seriously, this game punched me repeatedly in the feels. My eyes are puffy, my nose is runny, and my heart is achy.

Both the gameplay and the puzzles are pretty simple. A handful of puzzles took me a little more time to solve, but nothing that stumped me to the point of seeking outside assistance. The game design is also simple, but it suits the mood of the story extremely well. The characters and story itself are what made this such a fantastic experience, and the music is A+. 

If you're actively depressed or sensitive to character death - quick reminder, this story takes place in a hospital - I don't recommend this game to you. If you want something poignant, something both tragically bitter and fantastically sweet - give this game a shot. It's absolutely worth the price.

91303142.review:
Rakuen es un juego que te guía a través de la historia principal. "Tu, junto al protagonista deben despertar al guardián del bosque para pedirle un deseo". Y no es sencillo llegar a esa meta. Pero precisamente por eso es más emocionante. La historia general se divide en 2 mundos, un mundo real en un hospital donde todo es bastante dificil, y el mundo fantástico con el que el prota está conectado. 
Tenés que hacer misiones para obtener items que te sirven para otras cosas (o bien abrirte paso o para poder cumplir misiones para otros personajes, para a su vez poder cumplir la misión principal.) En muchos, (si no es que en la mayoría) tenés que resolver puzzles para seguir avanzando y durante toda la trama, podría decir que actuas como si fueras un detective). 
La música (como era de esperarse) juega un papel muy importante y además es una excelente compañía que da ambiente y resalta la emotividad de las historias.  ¿Dije historias? Si, LAS en plural.
Rakuen es un juego con una línea argumental principal de la cual se desprenden muchas ramas. (Las historias de los otros personajes del juego, lo cual me recuerda otro plus: Aunq los personajes secundarios no sean tantos, hasta los extras tienen su personalidad bien marcada y algo para decir) 
A mi parecer la historia principal y las historias de los personajes secundarios funcionan de manera simbiótica, ya que tanto el prota (o sea vos jugando a traves de él) como los personajes a los que ayudas, se benefician mutuamente con las acciones que desencadenas.  
Si es que hay algun punto flojo, diría que hay algunos momentos donde me estanqué, Y como en el juego hay partes que si no resolvés el misterio o el puzzle completo de la sala no te permite salir. Eso... me frustró un poquito. Pero creo q puede ser una prueba de perseverancia.  La verdad son muy poquitas ocasiones y no alcanzan para desestimar el juego, ni mucho menos la historia. 
Tal vez se me quede algo en el tintero, asi que puede que haga una reseña más extensa en video para yt
Por lo pronto les diré que Rakuen es una obra de arte inolvidable y se los mega recomiendo.
hasta la próxima
Kiaris ^^
