91108746.review:
This game is an emotional rollercoaster ride from start to finish. It's a beautifully designed game that will keep you breathless till the end. 

The game starts relatively cheery even though you are a little boy stuck in a hospital as you search for a missing book and meet the residents of your floor. From there you discover a beautiful parallel world filled with little creatures called Leebles as you adventure to wake the guardian of the forest, Morizora, in order to have him fulfill a wish for you. Once you are halfway through the game, I'd recommend having a box of tissues nearby as the game starts tugging on your heartstrings. It gets heavy and emotional, but always trying to look at the brighter side. 

The music is well thought out with the right types at the right time. With a beautiful melody you put together and a comical rap meets rock group called NO HOLDS BARD, the music is simply stunning.

This short little game is so beautifully designed, it can be hard to believe it's an RPG maker game. Laura Shigihara and her group did a fantastic job. 

So if you're looking for a short game (I played it through twice and have gotten all the achievements on the second run), with beautiful design that is a touching and heartfelt story, then look no further than Rakuen.

Thanks Laura!

you can find her on twitch developing new music and playing music on stream under "supershigi". 
Give her some love, she deserves it.

89948399.review:
What a strange game. What a great game.

This game surely gladdened my heart, messed with my mind and brought tears to my eyes.

What gladdened my heart: The mapping, the character art and charsets, the music and graphics are all just lovely. You can tell a lot of love has gone into this game. There is so many details to explore, there is actual songs in the game, and the stories are genuine and touching.

What messed with my mind: How the game seemingly doesn't want to tell you what in it is supposed to be reality and what is a dream or something similar of the main character. Also, the game is made up of parts that seem not to fit together. You often didn't know what the game would serve you next. Casual storytelling, tragedy, comedy, horror, serious topics and childlikeness ... but it just boldly stiches all of these things together anyway. And it works. Somehow. That's part of what makes this game so unique. Maybe the transition of e.g. horror to childlike fantasy world and back made me experience each more deeply, actually. I found the horror scenes terrible, just wanting to get out of there, maybe precisely because they contrasted with such fluffly happy fantasy world scenes. I was relieved to get back to the fluffly fantasy world exactly because it was such a relief to get away from the sad or frightening hospital. Just like a person actually stuck in a hospital might feel, wanting to escape, but also having to face their inner sadness and fear.

What brought tears to my eyes: The sadness in the story arcs. You would think that part of the game taking place in a hospital unit with [spoiler]terminally ill[/spoiler] patients would be enough to make it a sad story, but they all have their backstories as well. Still, often by working through the darkness, new hope is found.

Other comments: 1. The game seems to support a worldview that everyone goes to a good place after they die. 2. The pacing seemed a little off sometimes. Also when going through Rakuen doors, sometimes you end up in a hallway, sometimes in a new scene, sometimes first in one then in the other, it's confusing. But one can overlook that due to the many strengths of the game. 3. Again, the mapping is just so, so good and lovely, including all the custom graphics. Wow! And did I mention the graphics and the mapping are great? indeed, I need to say it three times, they were that good!

87765383.review:
It's a simple rpg story game made with rpg maker. The story is definitely unique which starts out with a boy in a hospital and he meets many different colorful characters has an emotional story. I don't want to spoil much so its best to play through and find out ;p .  The gameplay reminds me of older snes games during 90s era like Final Fantasy or Legend of Zelda. There is no combat or random enemy encounters in the game. Basic controls and nothing hard especially if you are using the walkthrough guide. It's all just exploring and talking to npcs. There a few times you do have to run from ghosts/bad spirits. The music is made by Laura Shigihara aka Supershigi which is definitely worth listening to. She also has a twitch channel which she plays live music from this game and other games she helped composed the music for which definitely worth checking out.  

I would say the only downside to the game is once you complete it there isn't anything else left to do. Not much replay value unless after a long time you feel like playing it again. I've 100% the achievement with the guide and it took about 8 hours on average. The dialogue is what makes it a bit longer but its a very story driven game and worth playing at least once. The soundtrack is worth listening to many times :)

87703591.review:
Beautiful child-friendly story with adorable characters, accompanied by great art and music; including a few musical moments.
I played this 2 times, aided by bad memory (totally forgot I'd played it before) and my previous saved was wiped.
It meant I could could go get 100% this time around though.
Most guides are very spoiler conscious and worth while at later points in the game as they won't ruin things usually.

I love this game but let me go over accessibility points and features.

**THEMES & TWs:**
Childhood, Disability, Trauma, Resilience, and Mortality. 
It's set in a hospital so obvious Trigger Warnings for Medical content, Illness, and Mortality.

**CONTROLS**
+The controls of this game are keyboard only (laptop friendly), or you can use keyboard and mouse (PC friendly). This makes the game very accessible. 
+There are very few segments that require speed and you can retry them without any penalties, because you don't have any punishments for 'passing out' during this game.
+A potato can run this.
-Sometimes the game runs slowly, not sure why as my computer is far beyond a potato... But as a result sometimes the movements are a lil bit delayed and I'd be unsure if they were stopping for a delayed scene or because the controls were being janky.

**VISUALS**
+Adorable pixel RPG/anime style visuals, with beautiful backgrounds. The designs of the worlds is unique, varied, imaginative and full of childlike wonder. You could never get bored with the creatures and visuals of this game!
-During changes between locations there is often a bright white page effect which is jarring and uncomfortable (I'm light sensitive and have chronic migraines). Because the game runs slowly for me, it often would just linger on this section for too long as well.
-Sometimes segments have really dark, limited visuals, where you have to be fast. I'm unsure how some of these segments worked for colourblindness either. I could navigate them if I turned up the brightness personally but I'm not sure how widely accessible it was.
-The screen shakes in one scene I believe, this only happens once but you're expected to move about quickly during it, and this triggered my vertigo! It'd be nice to be able to disable that kind of effect or have it it at the beginning of the scene but not during the whole actionable part of it. There could be other ways to signal movement I imagine.

**SOUND**
+Sound is great, with a variety of nice songs and BG music, and the odd sound effect; none were too jarring (besides phones ringing occasionally).
+You have subtitles for everything, including the singing.

**SAVING**
+You can save at any point except during cut scenes. 
-In fact you can't even *pause* during cut scenes! Although usually you need to click to continue each segment of dialogue, it doesn't replace the need for pausing. In my case, I pass out randomly, and being able to pause when I feel it coming on can save my laptop heating up over nothing, or making my loose my place when my cat decides she wants to continue the game while I'm out! 
-Also the last cut scene continues without your pressing anything, which... I mean, I was in the middle of crying my eyes out so I actually missed some of the ending content because of that lol!

Extra points because the game handles disabilities for a variety of ages, both physical and mental, without resorting to inspiration p*rn.

I fully recommend this game.

**What could make it better?**

*Ability to pause or quit during cut scenes, especially during the ending so we don't miss parts of it!
*An ability to opt in or out of additionally immersive features such as shaking screen, bright white light fade outs/ins, might be helpful.


Overall, I fully recommend this game. I feel it's pretty accessible, and handles its subjects sensitively and with respect, while being child friendly and heart warming. Prepare the feels though, they will be had!

I didn't want Rakuen to end. I wanted more, and I think that's a pretty defining factor of a well-made game.

The characters in Rakuen will find a way to reach your heart, one way or another. I believe that anyone can relate to their  stories and personalities, and it will change your life for the better. On the outside, it looks like your typical JRPG, but Rakuen is so much more than that. The narrative guides you into this collection of deeply interwoven stories all taking place in a small hospital wing as you take the role of a young boy with his own difficulties to face. Going through each character's story is a journey of emotion and it truly shines light on  subjects that can be very close to the heart, such as the values of family, morality,  integrity, and common decency. 

In a nutshell, it's wholesome. This is the kind of game that reminds you to not take any second of life for granted, be creative, and always be true to yourself. It is worth playing. I've played through it once and still have to play it, because I haven't gotten my Towel Cape achievement yet! 

Thanks for the great game Laura and everyone else who assisted in the creation <3 It's a delightful masterpiece.

85741938.review:
[h1]Rakuen is the apex of storytelling[/h1]
I have been putting off writing this review for nearly a year because Rakuen left me absolutely speechless, in the best way possible; I simply didn’t know how to put into words just how amazing this game is in a way that did it justice, so this is my best attempt.

[h1]Be prepared to cry happy tears[/h1]
This game knows just how to tug at all the right heartstrings.  Each of the character arcs is beautifully crafted and the world that the devs have built is both stunning and captivating.  Rakuen uses the lens of childhood wonderment and curiosity to explore many grown-up themes.  This unique point of view makes these tough topics more approachable & accessible in a tasteful way that all ages are sure to enjoy.

[h1]Timeless & unique design[/h1]
Rakuen may have been released nearly 4 years ago, but it is arguably even more pertinent to the world today than it was upon release.  The story hinges on an eccentric, fantastical duality of parallel worlds, akin to the whimsical manner that Miyazaki films often do.  By the same token, Rakuen both capitalizes on and redelivers the nostalgia of many retro JRPGs.  The game utilizes conventions pulled from these games from our childhoods in a way that I believe it would feel seamless for anyone to pick up.  Additionally, Rakuen introduces some one-of-a-kind mechanics of its own, such as talking to mom.  Unlike many JRPGs, however, there is no combat in the game;  Personally, this is one of the aspects I love most about this game, especially since Rakuen is such a well-written story that this decision truly allows for the narrative to take the front seat and drive the game forward.

[h1]The most impressive game to utilize the RPGMaker engine to date[/h1]
While it often seems to me as though the engine can be quite limiting for many devs and their visions, Rakuen utilized these at-times-restricting parameters in a way that is creatively advantageous and blows the platform out of the water.  With almost entirely custom assets, the portrait art & pixel sprites are beautifully executed—both cohesive in style and aesthetically exquisite.  As I mentioned, the character arcs are insanely well-crafted.  The plot includes excellent uses of foreshadowing without sacrificing unexpected plot twists.  The sound design and musical composition are at the level of masterpieces:  a true display of artistry and talent.  Both carry the story forward, and particularly the composition parallels how the storyline and characters build on one another in a very clever manner.

[h1]Other bits worth mentioning[/h1]
[list]
    [*]I spent 14 hours straight playing this game because I became so enveloped in the world of Rakuen that I simply could not bring myself to put it down 
    [*]I played using a Bluetooth DualShock controller, which integrated seamlessly and was a breeze to set up using the built-in controller set-up that is included in Steam
    [*]There were one or two times in the main area of the Leeble Forest where the game was a little laggy, which I believe was caused by the sunbeams & lighting effects overlays, but it was not enough to detract from my experience and this seems to be more of a personal symptom of my machine specs than the game itself, but I thought it might be worth noting
    [*]As this game is very simple yet incredibly effective, I’m certain this game could run on virtually any hardware
[/list]
[h1]If I had to pick one game out of the entire steam store, it would be this one.[/h1]
Words cannot describe how much love I hold for this game.  I am constantly wishing that I could play it again for the first time.  You will just have to play it to discover how beautiful this game is for yourself.

85606342.review:
This game means so much to me that I have tried to write a review for it at least 5 times but never posted it - because I felt like I wasn't doing justice to just how good it is. Instead of trying to express the overwhelming emotions I have regarding this game, I highly encourage you to experience it for yourself.

Rakuen is a story-based puzzle-solving adventure RPG. The graphics are adorable, the sound design and music are incredible, and the characters are so heart-wrenchingly human. Part of what makes this game so impactful and relatable is that there is something in it for everyone - whether you are a parent, a teen blossoming into adulthood, or someone finding your way around in life.

As for me, I grew up with severe life-threatening disabilities and spent much of my childhood (and current adult life) in hospitals. The way this game expresses and reflects the realities of how someone in my shoes feels was, for me, spot on. But it also gave me a lot more to think about and to reflect upon, to give me a new perspective to view my own life and how I may be affecting others. 

Laura Shigihara spent so much time and poured so much heart into making this game, and it shows.

I hope you will enjoy this game as much as I did. :)

85578956.review:
With [i]Rakuen[/i], developer Laura Shigihara put a lot of heart into making this game, wearing her influences on her sleeve to create a lush RPG world reminiscent of SNES classics. However, instead of combat and leveling, [i]Rakuen[/i] plays as a straightforward adventure game with  dungeon-like puzzle solving, meaningful character interactions and an emphasis on story. Having previously served as the lead composer for the first [i]Plants vs. Zombies[/i] and contributing songs to games like [i]To the Moon[/i] and [i]CS:GO[/i], Shigihara lends her acclaimed musical background to create an excellent score that bolsters an emotional story which explores pensive, existential themes with a childlike wonder. 

A few small nitpicks I have include: Some of the item collecting felt a bit arbitrary at points; the game seemed like it would eventually have a fast-travel option that it ultimately lacked (though I’m not sure if I’d actually use it); and (vague spoiler) [spoiler] since there are very few instances where one can get a “game over,” the few times where it [i]is[/i] possible struck me as rather jarring and out-of-place.[/spoiler]

As a whole, however, [i]Rakuen[/i] is a powerful, thought-provoking gaming experience. Knowing that this is Shigihara's first full foray into game development makes the game all the more impressive. It’s an easy recommendation, and a game I can see sticking with players long after its conclusion.

85292982.review:
If I had to choose one word to describe Rakuen, it would be bittersweet. The game draws you in with colorful environments, fun characters, and an "everyone has a story for you to uncover" narrative. On its surface, it's a game filled with hopes, dreams, and childlike wonder, but this is a vibrant coat of paint layered on top of of a deeper narrative about tragedy, loss, regret, and making the most of the time we have. Beneath its colorful cheery veneer lies a foundation of dulled colors and somber tones as you literally traverse the sad memories of your fellow patients. I thoroughly enjoyed the story and its characters, and shed tears more than once.

From a gameplay perspective, Rakuen is mostly about walking around and talking to people or looking at things and hoping to find something that will help you progress. The gameplay is strongest in its middle third as you explore the two most fleshed out memory segments. You'll search for keys, read notes, and solve some visual and sound-based puzzles. Nothing too difficult, but assembled well enough to be interesting. The first third of the game is fine enough, but the last third of the game the story is broken up mostly by you walking around and talking to people or collecting materials lying on the ground around Morizora's forest in lieu of the more mysterious memory dungeons. This section of the game is servicable, and you meet and interact with fun interesting characters. If that was the entire game I would still certainly enjoy it, but the first two memory dungeons write a check that the rest of the game fails to cash and it is a little disappointing. Gameplay is definitely the weakest point of Rakuen, and honestly it probably could have done with less- I'll stand by the two memory dungeons being positive examples of gameplay, but even in those segments that I thought stood out the slow pace of the character's walking made them drag on quite a bit. Most of the gameplay feels in the way of the story instead of in service of it.

The music is incredible, I bought the game because Laura Shigihara is one of my favorite composers. I found myself dancing to a few of the zone tunes on more than one occasion, and the songs with vocals are all fantasic.

If you're looking for a heartwarming story and you're fine with a game hitting you right in the feels when you least expect it, Rakuen is an experience I wholeheartedly recommend.

84583128.review:
**Before reading this review, please keep in mind that this is MY opinion and shouldn't affect how other people view this game**

I got this game from a friend of mine for Christmas, and though I wasn't sure what to expect, I decided to give it a shot. And wow, was it worth it. So, the story is about a hospitalized boy and his mother who go on an adventure to a magical land in order for him to ask the Guardian of the Forest for a wish. In the process, he also learns more about the other people hospitalized in the same hospital.

So, usually when playing different games that I know I will review later, I tend to write on a document the things that I like, am mixed about, and dislike as I play along with the game. For this game, however, I didn't think to do it, so I am just going to be naming off some things off the top of my mind.

Alright, so let's start with the things I liked:
1. The story: So, the story from the beginning i found pretty interesting (though I feel going to a whole other world can be a bit cliche), but what really compensated for that was the twists and turns the story took. Like, I love how it was divided into 5 segments, one for each character that you were trying to help out. And well, despite how it made me cry, the story combined incredibly well and it felt really wholesome and complete by the end of it.
2. The characters: I just love how there are two different variations of each character (One in each world), and how creative the designs were for the fantasy world characters, and how they mixed in with something that the character in the real life loved.
3. The music: Something tells me I am going to end up repeating the music of the game, to listen to all the time. It was very soothing, most of the times. But felt more fast paced and stressful in dangerous situations, which is a plus.

Sooo, those are the things I can think of on the top of my head.
Now, for the thing I didn't like about the game which was:
How slow it felt sometimes.
Like, I am not against searching for things, it's actually pretty interesting. But there were some points (especially in the cave) that I just started feeling like it was getting a bit tedious. Though, once I pushed past that, I felt it was pretty nice, so I would say it's not superr bad.

But anyway, that's what I have to say. Shorter than my usual reviews, but yeah.
Overall, I would say I really enjoyed playing this game and would recommend this to anybody who wants some adventure with some touching stories too.

I feel a bit bad giving this a thumbs down since I get the feeling it's been made by a small team and they clearly put a lot of love into it but I honestly can't recommend it. Within the first 2 hours I pretty much had the plot on point give or take a bit and it felt like I was going through the motions, the gameplay was tedious, boring and distracting from the story and overall it felt like I was being told "you should feel something for person X".

It's a shame because like others I found this simply because of To the Moon and Finding Paradise and this seemed like it could hit that same itch for an amazing story but instead I felt very little connection to the characters mostly because of very little time spent on each since most of the time you are either walking around or solving 'puzzles'. The end I had seen coming for a while and when I got there I just went "as expected" and I didn't really feel much to it since, to be honest everything was just too vague, (without giving away spoilers) I get that it's trying to be metaphorical and let you make your own story out of it but that only goes so far, a lot of what happens just doesn't make sense to me at least.

So if you are looking for something to play that's an OK story and you spend most of you're time just walking around, watching animations happen and being left with a feeling of "well that was alright" then you probably want to play this. If you're looking for a really good story game that really smacks you in the feels then look else where.

Rakuen is the story of a little hero living in a hospital ward with his mother and many other patients. His goal is to help as many people as possible, and awaken the guardian of the forest Morizora to grant his wish and go to Rakuen, a magical paradise. To do this, the boy must traverse to a parallel fantasy world with his mother and search for lost people and items, and take on quests to bring everyone together again.  

Rakuen is a heartwarming and heartwrenching story and I genuinely enjoy and recommend it. Tragedies told through the perspective of a child who got dealt with a bad hand by fate, it’s unlike anything I’ve ever experienced. The music is memorable and the story is interesting and charming. A heart-warming, wholesome story. It's of the kind of story that takes the mundane and really enchants it. A boy stuck in the hospital goes around exploring, and the hospital becomes an adventurable place. Each of the patients has a story, and you learn about it by talking to them, and then help them overcome their sorrow in a parallel fantasy world. The fantasy world is beautiful. The soundtrack is beautiful and I can easily listen to it on repeat.

Mom tags along! How great is that? It leaves me reflecting on a parent's love and guidance.

I really want to see more of this kind of game. Too many RPG's are based on simple fighting. There's no combat here but lots to keep you engaged. Riddles, helping people, making the roots happy so that the silo apple tree can be beautiful, etc.

81608773.review:
For what it is, it's alright, but I don't think I'd replay it in the future. (Please disregard my total playtime; I left the game running for a couple of hours while I went out to go grocery shopping!)

Pros:
-The art style is very polished and clean, particularly the character portraits.
-The instrumental music is very nice and fits the atmosphere.
-It's nice that the mom is such an important character. 
-Sue's story was nice.
-You can 100% the achievements in the game in one playthrough.

Cons:
-At times it can be a chore to play (particularly the "dark" sections). Some sections of the game were so tedious I debated just giving up, but some part of me insisted on seeing the story through to its end (more on that later). I would not call a good majority of this game fun.
-As other reviews have mentioned, some of the songs have rather cheesy lyrics to the point they were kind of awkward to listen to. 
-The story itself is very easy to predict, so all of the "big reveals" can be seen coming far in advance. Might just be that I'm very familiar with a lot of the story beats from playing other games, but when I guessed what direction the ending was going to take within the first half-hour of playing, it made the journey to reach said ending rather lackluster since I already knew what was going to happen. 
-As a whole, the game felt like it was aimed at a lot younger target audience, but the subject matter and puzzle difficulty doesn't match this. As another review mentioned, the game might be enjoyable to play with a young child as your "co-pilot," given they're mature enough to understand the concept of death (which is kind of funny considering the two main characters of the game).
-Walking speed was awfully slow (though I believe another player has created a patch that lets you run). Normally for a game made in this engine it would be easy to ignore but with the amount of backtracking and fetch quests, this does not help alleviate the tedium.

It's not a bad game, but it's not a particularly noteworthy game either. This is a situation where I'd rate the game as neutral rather than positive or negative, but I guess as it stands, the cons outweigh the pros.

78989986.review:
I played Kan Gao's games such as To the Moon a while back, beautiful games. Changed my mind about RPG Maker games, my reviews of them are glowing but that's not what this review is about.
Anyway I recognized the person who created this game (kudos to their great team too, of course)
because she was the singer in some beautiful songs from those games. I figured this game had to be great!
Sure enough it was.
Most of it is this cute innocuous stuff, sometimes funny, sometimes really true.
Of course it's pretty heavy at times.
Lots of great points where I realized a thing called back to something that I saw in the early game, and every time it felt amazing to see my realizations confirmed.
I really admire the mom, she's the real hero. Rad Mom is amazing!
The boy is truly the greatest warrior in the forest, I cheered for him and all the characters whose desires he desired for them.
The ending made me cry.
And of course the songs were beautiful again.
In my experience, losing a loved one is really hard and you feel it the rest of your life.
It's part of the human experience, I think. And everyone will have to feel it someday.
We can't just dismiss anger, worry, and fear by calm reasoning.
We need to show empathy and kindness. Actually show it show it.
In the face of disaster, it is a noble thing to be able to sacrifice yourself for the sake of others.
Even if they are doing it wrong or failing, people who are helping with their heart in the right place portray that nobility.

Thank you Laura, for a noble and bittersweet game that I can really take to heart.

Make-A-Wish Foundation poster child!
10/10

78689174.review:
Bueno... este es uno de esos juegos que no quiero volver a jugar, pero que seguramente volveré a hacerlo por recordar algo: su indescriptible belleza. [i]Rakuen[/i] llegó a mis manos luego de ver una publicación por parte de Kan Gao, autor de [i]To the Moon[/i] y [i]A Bird Story[/i], donde lo recomendaba y anunciando que era un juego de Laura Shigihara, quien canta en [i]To the Moon[/i] y [i]Plants vs. Zombies[/i]. Como muchos de los juegos que adquiero, este se quedó en la juegoteca acumulando polvo hasta que empecé a jugarlo. El juego narra la historia de un hospital donde un niño debe acercarse a otros pacientes, conocerlos un poco y ayudarlos a encontrar una resolución a sus historias personales a través de un mundo paralelo que se encuentra disponible para él a través de de un libro: [i]Rakuen[/i]. Antes de adquirir este juego, te advierto que no es un videojuego en sí, es simplemente una novela visual interactiva, por lo que el corazón de este producto es básicamente su historia y no su excelente y novedosa jubabilidad, pues no la tiene.

📖 Tiene logros y cromos en Steam.
📖 Puedes jugarlo con el teclado o el ratón.
📖 Ya que está hecho con RPG Maker XP y no es un juego muy grande, no exige mucho espacio de almacenamiento en a computadora.
📖 Cuenta con salvado y autosalvado, ambos bastante accesibles en cualquier momento de la historia.
📖 La historia es bella y conmovedora en un todo, así como las historias independientes en su interior.
📖 Tiene más interactividad que otras novelas visuales hechas con RPG Maker, pues hay objetos adquiribles que son útiles durante toda la historia, así como otros tantos que sirven propósitos estéticos y de compleción de logros.
📖 Se juega en modo ventana 640x480 (o si te pasó a ti que repentinamente se agrandó a toda la pantalla, presiona Alt+Enter para achicarla).
📖 Hay una banda sonora y una pequeña animación en 3D disponibles en la tienda de Steam.
📖 La duración de la historia es corta, unas diez horas en total incluyendo la compleción de logros.
📖 El lenguaje del juego es inglés, pero la interfaz y los subtítulos están disponibles en español.
📖 Hay un pequeño juego de recolección que, aunque breve y sencillo, es divertido.

📕 Adivina, sí hay Game Over y este es cuando te sumerges en el agua por mucho tiempo sin regresar a respirar. Lo bueno es que te devuelve a un punto de autosalvado que suele ser poco antes de entrar.
📕 Se juega en modo ventana 640x480 (o si te pasó a ti que repentinamente se agrandó a toda la pantalla, presiona Alt+Enter para achicarla). Sí, un punto repetido, pero es ambivalente.
📕 El juego y sus añadidos (banda sonora y la animación) en un todo son algo costosos para el concepto general de una novela visual, algo alrededor de entre los dos y quince dólares (al menos aquí en Perú), pero creo que aun así lo vale. De todas formas podrías ver de adquirirlo en época de ofertas.
📕 Se requiere de pañuelos desechables para cada vez que haya que moquear y llorar.

76532908.review:
Rakuen is a pseudo-game with a mediocre pretentious story and an awful gameplay.

[b] Pros: [/b]
+ Some parts of the pixel art is neat.
+ Music is above average.

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Gameplay. It might be a visual novel as well (not that im against them), in fact it should have suit the game better, since all gameplay is simply go there, go there, return there, now go there... It cripples the story, tedious, slow and uninspiring. Now i understand very well why gameplay of the "to the moon" (which i adore) was so basic, it never got in the way of the story. I mean it is like reading a book and when you try to turn the page someone sits on your neck and forces you for a hundred push-ups to continue. And dont even make me start about the childish puzzles... all garbage. What a waste.
- Story. Besides the gameplay, this is my main problem with it. Story isnt that grand either to make me endure the disgusting gameplay it has. Story is pretentious, everything is too obvious, characters are bland and 2-dimensional, plot holes there and there, forced emotions... Congratulations for putting every writing mistake in a story. Zero engagement. What i find interesting is, majority of people who loved "To The Moon" also loved this game... How?... Really, how?.. You have one sci-fi/drama masterpiece in one hand, and one pretentious/amateurish/uninspired common fantasy story going nowhere on the other hand... How did you manage to love them both, congrats...
- Visual representation. Since it so forcibly tries to emulate to be a story-telling medium, instead of graphics, ill inspect it as a visual representation of a story. Well, it is uninspired (if you are not making it a book, just give me something i didnt see before right?). Has no specific style or uniqueness. Just plain charm of some neat pixel art. This is another thing with the game: mediocrity, i mean everywhere...

[b] Final: [/b]
2/10 Boring, uninspired, bland. I know you'll see a lot positive reviews, just beware and take my points into consideration before jumping blindly into a silly fan-vagon.

Rakuen is a story of kindness and resilience, coupled with elements of amazingly-built fantasy worlds and simple dialogue. I was put to tears several times while playing the game - proof enough that video games can be powerful methods of storytelling.

76350223.review:
I just want to start this off by saying that I had bought this game 3 years ago thinking it was a very different game than what it was, and while I do regret waiting this long to play the game I am very satisfied and happy I did finally play this game.  I will be posting a more detailed review here shortly since there isn't enough characters, but this is a rough idea of it all.

I had initially thought that this game would take place solely in a fantasy world, so I was surprised when I learned it would take place both in the hospital and in the fantasy world (though I should have seen that coming given the game description).  Even though it was very different than what I thought it was going to be initially, I still thought this was a very, very good game.

[u]ART:[/u]
I have always loved RPG/JRPG games and they have a special place in my heart, and this one is no different.  The art is absolutely beautiful and I love the designs for everything.  The color scheme and designs for Morizora's forest were created very well.  The environment was green and blooming, the grey sky (while not too dark) gave off the feeling that a storm had passed/a storm was coming (as the story goes into detail with later).  It was also a very good change in comparison to the hospital setting.  There wasn't a lot of color outside of the plants that were randomly placed throughout.  However, hospitals sometimes give off a feeling of being uncomfortable or distressing, and this particular setting didn't feel so.  It, of course, felt busy because of all the hospital personnel bustling around everywhere, but for the most part it felt like just another day (of which it was for the Boy who essentially lived in the hospital).

[u]CHARACTERS:[/u]
Every character design and their background was lovingly made.  Even though a lot of the characters had much different designs than they did in Morizora's forest, you could absolutely recognize who everyone was and represented.  All the Leebles and support characters (especially the Envoy) were definitely very cool design choices and characters, so well done on their creation!! 

[u]SOUNDTRACK:[/u]
The soundtrack was absolutely beautiful and there was a lot of love put into the music made.  All the music was different for the different locations, and you could tell how the game was going based on the tune.  I was absolutely terrified for the first chapter of the game because of how often the scary music was played.  It was certainly good though and I give props to the team that made all the music, especially the vocals!!  I absolutely loved it and will be listening to it in the future.

[u]ENDING:[/u]
There is honestly so much to say there that I don't have the space for it (so maybe I'll post a separate discussion on my interpretation of the endings).  Everything was done so well, and everything fits in with the information given.  As many people have already said, it is absolutely a cry fest so be prepared for a flurry of emotions.  

Overall, this is an absolutely fantastic game and I am so glad I got the chance to play it.  I wasn't ready for all the emotions, but this is definitely a very special game that I would play again.  Thank you so much Laura Shigihara for giving us the opportunity to play this game!!!

75967026.review:
Rakuen (paradise, in Japanese), is a game about the journey of a mother and her son.

[spoiler] This game takes place in Japan after a certain historical tragedy, that most of us were probably alive during and know, of left Japan devastated. The game does not really outright say what it was but the gameplay and notes leave strong hints about it and give you insight to the lore. [/spoiler]
^not a huge spoiler, just a bit of premise and setting, but if you want to try to discover everything for yourself than I suggest not reading.


Humor - from helping tree feet to drinking tea with flowers, this game had me laughing so hard I cried. The characters all have something to say and it is worth talking to each and every one of them. 10/10

Puzzles - the puzzles were challenging, but never impossible. Most puzzles were easy, but usually in a way that made me feel smart and clever. There were some that stumped me but I was able to figure them out after a bit of time and thought. This game does not rely on cheap mechanics like hiding things where you would never look. There is a clue for everything and the clues are never too obscure or vague. 10/10

Music - the music was the big mood-setter for the game. It guided your emotions for every scene. Sometimes it would be somber and pretty, other times it was upbeat and fun. Loved all of the singing as well. 10/10

Characters - the characters are deep and real. I do not mean that they are people who actually exist. I mean that their situations are very real and that they convey those situations perfectly. For example, Kisaburo reminds me a bit of what my grandpa is going through. All the characters have humor, motives, and stories that I think you will enjoy. 10/10

Animation - although almost everything is pixelated and it is not the amazing realistic graphics that we have grown used to at this point in time, it is still beautiful. I remember the stars, the forests, the ponds. It was all beautiful. Which is why I say this is some of the best pixelated animation of all time. 10/10

Writing - if I have any complaint with the game, it would be in the writing. No, I do not mean the overall writing of the plot. I mean the actual writing when someone is speaking and my only complaint is that one time mom said "prolly" and i thought that was strange. Overall, I did not even notice any typos or weird grammar. It all flowed very well and the plot writing is near perfection. 10/10

In conclusion, this game had me laughing, fully invested, and motivated to help everyone. Not because I'm a good person or anything, but because the game made me fall in love with the characters. And I'll leave it at this as to not spoil anything: I most certainly lost the "try not to cry" challenge...

I found Rakuen after playing To The Moon and Finding Paradise, both of which I love very much. First of all, the story of Rakuen is beautiful, imaginative and emotional. I love the story, especially the ending which was very emotional. Regarding the game play, I find Rakuen has a stronger emphasis on "game" than To The Moon and Finding Paradise. TTM and FP are like interactive stories while Rakuen is more like a game, with more time exploring around, talking to different NPCs, collecting items and completing tasks. I find TTM style more enjoyable but this is just personal preference. In the middle of Rakuen game play I was a bit bored by the game play mechanism where I have to go around and collect items or help out NPCs who are not on the main story line on somewhat trivial tasks. One example is the task of serving tea and finding the thief at Skybud mansion. All I want to do is bring the tea sample to Monsieur and find out what happens next on  Kisaburo story line. Personally I find this kind of chore-like tasks to be a distraction from the main story, and I might enjoy the story better with less of them. Still, all the chores are worth it to go through for the end of the story. The part after Star Night Festival night was truly amazing. Overall, I really like this game and thank you Laura for creating it.

P.S. I'm not sure why Steam counted 111 hours on the game. Maybe I once left the game running while I was away. The actual time I spent on it was about 11 hours.

75009366.review:
It's difficult to know how to review Rakuen. If you go in thinking of it as a game, you may be disappointed. It is more like a visual novel, with the controls and appearance of an old-school JRPG (it was made using RPG Maker - though unlike many games made with that software, the assets seem largely original, and have a great deal of charm). 

Set between a hospital in the "real" world and the "imaginary" world of Morizora's Forest, the game follows a boy, a patient at the hospital, as he seeks to earn a wish from a legendary spirit - a character from the story book his mother often reads to him. The "gameplay", such as is, involves talking to characters, collecting items and solving basic puzzles. The story is roughly divided into 4-5 sections focused on different characters at the hospital, all struggling with different problems. These character-focused sections are very linear, while the parts in between offer a little more freedom to explore.

 My favourite aspects of Rakuen are the ways the real and imaginary worlds intersect, to the point where it's hard to tell where one ends and the other begins. I like how the creator didn't insist on spelling out the nature of reality in the game, instead leaving it open to interpretation. I also think the game earns it own tears, in a way that To The Moon, to which it is often compared (both are made in RPG Maker, and Rakuen's creator did some music for To The Moon) doesn't, in my opinion. 

On the downside, I felt that the limitations of RPG Maker showed in the depictions of the various stories. The characters are all dealing with issues that are very familiar to anyone who's watched network TV over the last 20 years. That's not to say that those issues are too worn-out for use, but the limited scope for depiction in a 2D game with limited animation, relying mainly on written dialogue to convey the story, makes them all feel a little staid. 

Also, as I mentioned before, there isn't much "game" to this game. The story is worthwhile, but I feel like I would have had a more enjoyable experience reading this as a picture book (I say picture book, as the art deserves to be seen). While there are some puzzles in the early game, by about midway through, they essentially disappear. The earlier flashback sequences have a few puzzles, but the latter ones purely involve talking to the right character or interacting with the right object to advance the story. I think if you put something in game format, it should at minimum have fun gameplay, or give the player choice in how to approach things, and Rakuen doesn't really try to do either. I also have issues with the ending, but I don't want to leave any spoilers here. 

If gameplay is less important to you than plot, and you like emotion-filled stories and whimsical characters, then I recommend Rakuen. If you're looking for a fun gaming experience, rather than a story book in game form, you should probably look elsewhere.

73728519.review:
I give this game a 3/5: it could have been better, but I like it enough for what it is. MAJOR spoilers discussed below.

I'm trying to give it some slack because it is, after all, an indie game, and I do massively respect what Ms. Shigihara and team accomplished here. It's an incredibly charming game with loads of heart—it tries very hard to present the emotions within as honestly and directly as it can, and the result is very real, very human characters. I feel invested in what their fates will be, and whether or not they'll be okay (this is why I liked the mini-dungeons associated with each patient so much, and why I was disappointed they petered out after the first two song quests!)

I must point out, however, that the game sometimes relies too heavily on its emotionality, often leaving the story pace floundering. How is a player to know Kisaburo has died after his quest, when he is simply nowhere to be found afterwards and no one makes mention of this? How did Puchi make her way back to Sue in the hospital, when she was only found in the other world? And, most important to me, why did the boy choose to move on to Rakuen rather than cure his illness, and stay with his mother? What was the point of his journey and everything he learned if he can no longer apply it by the end? Perhaps this latter issue is just me missing the point—I imagine the game is trying to make a point about healing, resting, moving on, etc. But I can't help but notice the little snags in the logistics; they stick out to me like painful little barbs, keeping me from enjoying the game in the emotional way it wants me to—and that I would like.

Still, I'm glad it exists. I don't regret playing Rakuen, and highly suggest the reader tries it for themselves—it is, at its core, a genuine and heartwarming/heartbreaking experience, and despite my hang-ups, it did make me emotional at the very end. Check it out!

In fact, writer/creator/composer/everything else Laura Shigihara actively encourages emotions to run raw and be expressed. Rakuen isn't just the journey of a boy and his mother, it's a journey of empathy for everyone. Shigihara's way of hitting just the right tone and notes in both her writing and her music makes me wonder just what she has experienced to write such a powerful narrative, but as Mom says in the game - be a lighthouse for other people and shine your light. Wow, I finally got around to playing this game after having it be on my wishlist for so long. Come COVID time, I was able to sit down and give it the due diligence it deserves. 

This is a beautiful game and it shines on so many levels. It does what I think games should do now, tell a compelling story within the medium. Gaming genres are often defined by their mechanics, which I think is a disservice to gaming in general, because the medium fails to tell interesting stories while in pursuit of more interesting mechanics.

Rakuen uses a straightforward engine and molds and shapes it into a tale that will tug the heartstrings and delight the soul.

The game is an overall delight, but I want to call out the music in particular. Laura Shigihara is an exceptional musician and all the music in this game is amazing.

It's well worth the time and money to experience this game.

73025110.review:
Outstanding. 
[i]Rakuen[/i] is a game with many facets and Laura Shigihara’s (of [i]To the Moon[/i] fame) first game created by herself. I would say, the experiment was more than successful. To get the basics out of the way, much like [i]To the Moon[/i] before it, [i]Rakuen[/i] is ultimately a 16-bit styled RPG-Maker game. It is rather light on gameplay and instead focuses very much on telling not just one, but several interconnected stories.
The gameplay is where I would see flaws, as it did at times seem rather disruptive to the experience, when you go from enjoying heavy narrative focus to collecting items and solving switch puzzles to progress towards the next part of the plot. In this sense, the game did at times seem a bit confused as to what it wants to be, a more traditional game or a vehicle for player-driven narrative. This does not actually mar it all that much, but the impression nevertheless stayed with me.
As for more technical aspects, the graphics are certainly more than fine. Beautiful portraits for dialogue await, as well as some truly nice animations during the game. And whilst this is certainly aiding the game greatly, the most amazing aspect aside from the plot is the music. And as it should be in this kind of game, the soundtrack is a deeply emotional rollercoaster, written with narrative in mind, which might stay with you long after you are done.
This brings us to the actual narrative. A story set in a hospital ward, where the player character is a little boy visited by his mother is not unlikely to have its disheartening moments, no matter the eventual outcome. Without giving away too much, it is a story about finding closure and coming to terms with things, most importantly dealing with loss. A state of loss in one way or another is given for most characters and as you learn more and more about the circumstances of both the current state of the diegetic world, as well as the individual people’s backgrounds and problems you can try to understand and maybe even improve their situation. In this sense it is a very “human” story, empty as it may sound, a story of empathy and comfort. What makes it interesting for me are the various perspectives, as we constantly switch from a more child-like perspective to adult ones. In addition, the concept of the two worlds, real and fantasy, adds another layer to it all, juxtaposing a real-world version opposed by metaphor-laden fantasy. Or [i]is[/i] it fantasy at all? There is a certain profoundness to be found in the game’s themes and the stories it has to tell.
By the way, although by no means required, it is a nice bonus to know a little something of both the Japanese language, as well as Japanese history. I could certainly appreciate the inter-cultural aspects of it all.

[h1] Rakuen [/h1]
This game, This game is everything. Not a lot of people knows about this game but i really hope my review could get some people attention. Short story for this game: i bought this game back then at 2017 cuz it looks cool but throughout the story progression it gets way more better. at the end i cried. And now it's how me and my girlfriend get close together, she used to watch me playing this game until i finish it. this game touched her heart and she really enjoyed watching me play, we even cried together at the ending hehe.

[b] Warning might contain spoilers, i will censor the spoiler parts so proceed with your own caution[/b]

[h1] Things i like: [/h1]
- The Soundtrack:
If i'm not mistaken Laura Shigihara is the Music producer for this game, along side with her friends too. But as we all know about Laura, every song that she creates always fits with the game so i'm telling y'all [b] the song is a banger and also very emotional [/b]

- The Characters:
As we Progress into the Story we wont just be seeing more humans, we will meet some creatures like it's shown on the Trailer, Leebles. Personally i love them, they look cute. But the main thing is the Character development throughout the story is very impressive.

- The Art:
I was quite surprised that even a 2D-ish like game would look this beautiful. The Sprites that this game has to offer looks very great too.

- The Story: [b] Warning, Might contain spoiler! [/b]
[spoiler] The Story,, It's very goddamn Incredible, Emotional, Magnificent. I might be the only one who's overreacting but the amount of deaths in this game is insanely high yet saddening (in a good way). It's not a combat game but the backstory for every each NPC (including your character) has almost at least 1 death,, at the very second right now i could cry remembering what happened to Sue... [/spoiler]

- The Morals From The Game:
Now i don't want to spoil much with this but if you play the game, you'd understand.

[h1] The Things I dislike: [/h1]
- The Options Settings:
It would be nice to have a small update just for settings, It'd really nice to have an option to lower the in-game volume OR choosing the game resolution! :) 

- The Keybinds:
The default keybinds are the arrow for movement and for interaction is,, uhh,, i can't remember but it's quite okay. But it'd be if we are able to change the keybinds, especially for the movement parts. Games lately do use W, A, S, D as their movement keys.

- THE SCARINESS AT THE 1st CHAPTER:
PLS OMG DON'T SCARE ME LIKE THAT, THE 1st AND 2nd CHAPTER WAS VERY SCARY IF YOU DON'T GET WHAT'S GOING ON AJSDJAHJDS. But i love it nonetheless.

[h1] Rating: [/h1]
Unfortunately there is nothing that is flawless in this world, every creation has flaws. I love this game the most, It's infact the 1st game that manages to make me cry so i respect you all devs. I rate this game [b] 9.6 [/b]!!!

[b] P.S: [/b] Hi Guys i'd like to thank all of you who takes your time to read this Review this game makes alot of differences on my life, as i said there's always flaw so i sincerely apologize if i made some mistake in this review :). When you do get the game  please do write more reviews and suggest it to other people too! not a lotta people knows about this game. It'd be very nice that everyone at least knows about this game existence. That's all from me, see y'all on the next review~ baiiii~

72829689.review:
As someone who first knew about Laura Shigihara thanks to "Plants vs. Zombies", it's amazing to see how far she has come. The fact how the idea/concept of "Rakuen" all started due to a song she wrote for a charity album years ago (such song is actually featured in the game!) makes this more great. And having fully experienced/played this game, it definitely shows.

What can I say? The gameplay is nice, character designs are great & cute, story arcs are so compelling that some, if not, many people may find themselves relate to in real life. And did I mention the music? Absolutely beautiful, never fails to please me.

All in all, "Rakuen" is such a wonderful game, definitely recommended. If you're into these kinds of stories wherein they have wholesome and emotional substances, then this game is for you. Here's a thought: why not play this game with your family? Would make up for a lovely experience.

Because of this game, the line "Keep shining your light." has struck on me, such an uplifting message/motto. To be honest, discovering about this game has helped me see the positive outlook of life better. And I just want to say, thank you Laura Shigihara and co. for making and bringing this excellent masterpiece to everyone. Keep up the good work and good luck on future endeavors/projects. Also, I want to give a shout-out to everyone I've met in her community, much love and thanks! It really really means a lot. Thanks again, and keep shining your light.

72145083.review:
Rakuen made me cry my eyes out. More than once. The story hooks you in from the start with more questions than answers — what's going on in the world? Who are these people I'm surrounded by? What's wrong with me? At least I have my mom there to hold my hand while I explore...

All of the characters feel well-developed. The music is fantastic — Laura Shigihara knows how to craft compelling songs that tie in to the story in thematic ways. It feels like a passion project, a love letter from the creator to the world. I grew up playing RPGs on NES and SNES, and many of the elements of the game remind me of those early games with lots of dialogue to make up for the lack of full motion video capture. The writing is fluid, full of jokes and yet serious at the same time. I can heartily recommend this game to anyone.

So, i bought this game on a whim. The art looked cute, no combat, light puzzle solving? Alright, im in! Boy, what a wild ride this game is. It takes several things i love in a game put them into (what I think is) an absolute masterpiece in storytelling.
I won't spoil anything, but i'm going to say that if you like playing games for the story, with a little bit of patience (Yes, the puzzles are kinda hard if you like rushing through for the story like me), this game is perfect. Characters are adorable, the art is great (both pixelated and the drawn out characters when they speak). I bought this for around $3, but i would easily say this is worth $10 or more just because of how incredible the games tells you heartbreaking stories for so many characters. Certain ones i think hit harder that others...but man..it's rough, but worth playing. I spent roughly 10 hours of gameplay on this, and im so happy i made the decision to buy this. It's great if you;re not a fan of combat, and there's a dev made walkthrough too which is super helpful, (thank u dev team!!!!) Love this game, go and buy it. Support these devs <3

71782168.review:
From the writing, to the artwork, to the awesome emotions evoked in this game, Rakuen, will capture your heart and soul, as it did mine!
The script's wording of each character's speech let's you imagine clearly that either a child or adult is talking. It is a realistic presentation of how folks really speak to each other & doesn't leave you with a robotic experience.
Each character is developed completely, which allows the player to find empathy for all of them.
The Mother is a central character, but not intrusive, so the Boy can grow and learn more about the world while she gently guides her son. I think if you love your mother, you will love Rakuen!
Your tears will flow, as mine did, but it will leave you with new hope for the future. I love this game for the way it made me feel. The games and mysteries are fun, but not too difficult. One of the most important aspects of the game is the music which transports you deep into the world of Rakuen. Huge Congratulations to the kind & clever author, composer, singer, & to the imaginative artist who made this game so memorable!

71556501.review:
Originally bought because it's on sale and because I knew this title from a Twitch streamer I was watching, I was not in the slightest bit disappointed about the quality of the game as well as the money spent on buying it. My opinion below is purely subjective, and I believe each person might have a different set of standards: the game is pretty well-made for me.

For the first couple of minutes, I do admit to not feeling entertained much by the plot. However, as the story progresses, the tipping point being my being introduced to the world of Rakuen, I can't help but be sucked in by the fantastic and magical visual and auditory experience presented in front. I kept on exploring locations, unlocking new collectibles and hours upon hours just pass by without my notice.

Story-wise, as a casual gamer, I feel like the story is good enough to seal the deal. Not spectacular, but it is in no way bad or average even. There are certain moments that pull my heartstrings, though most of the game is just quite chill which is also another thing I like about Rakuen. Suspense is present but only in some portions, and I actually prefer it more that they keep it at a low.

One con I can think of is that stuttering might frequently occur in parts where a dialogue appears above a character instead of the normal screen-wide box with a character illustration. But it might just be my potato acting up so it's negligible. Another con would be lack of game settings like full screen vs window mode, key re-binding,... Other than that, I can't seem to find any more cons atm.

Overall, the game is quite good (imo), and if you like RPG or relaxing games, definitely give this one a try.

71363662.review:
As a fan of Shigi, I learned about this game a few years ago but only got to play it recently. And it iS a game that needs to be played in 2020. In contrast to Shigi's cheerful and sunny disposition, this game goes into some really dark places and is not afraid to tackle heavy themes such as racism, PTSD, dementia and survivor's guilt. But despite all that, it wants you to believe that there is always hope for a brighter tomorrow so you have to pick yourself up and rise again despite the pain and suffering.

In 10 hours (or less) you will experience a roller coaster of emotions in this masterful piece of storytelling, and the music will stay even longer with you. As the composer, Shigi really did a masterful work with the music in this game and the songs will hit your feelings hard and make you weep. This game really shows you how much artistry and mastery can be done with RPG Maker and it really pushed the boundaries of what kind of storytelling can be achieved using the engine. One minor complaint is that the puzzles can be somewhat dragging and too long, especially during one part of the story, but other than that, this game is a real masterpiece.

Definitely recommended (especially in 2020) — 9.0/10

71153314.review:
A pretty little game with a lot of emotion and heart. With a single story to tell, 16-bit + portrait style art, no combat, and a melancholy-but-hopeful tone, this will immediately appeal to fans of games such as "To The Moon" and "OneShot". This game is more colorful than those, with a richly illustrated fantasy world and plenty of happy faces to go with the sad ones. The music is also very pretty, composed and in many cases performed by the adorable and accomplished Laura Shigihara, which makes the big plot points all the more impactful.

Lastly, this game features a great relationship between parent and child, and you will often be in control of this party of two with the option to chat or ask your mom for advice ('what to do next' hints). I've never seen that before and it was lovingly executed!

Bought this game on discount and, based on the reviews alone, also bought for a friend. We completed it at about the same time and both enjoyed it thoroughly. Would buy again even at full price if it were appropriate as a gift.

- Most of all, the HEART that must have gone into this game.

A great game where I felt overwhelmed by a number of things so I could only beat it in four sittings.

The game often shifts between being dark and cute. A few things in the story are not so clear either and I'm unsure what really happened with a few characters. The links between the real world and Rakuen are also not explained and I had to come up with my own ideas to fill the holes. If you don't like stories where key elements are not explained but simple things are, don't play this game.

It was also hard to tell what they wanted to achieve with a few puzzles being overly complicated. It's more of a personal thing since I hate numbered locks in game, where it could be a hundred different combinations, but hey, if you're into that, you do you. That problem only appeared once anyway, so it is not a major issue.

The game has many strong sides and I really liked the conclusion even if in my mind it was imagined differently that it had been foreshadowed before the end credits (if you play the game you'll understand). 
All in all a great game with amazing soundtracks which I might listen to once in a while.

8/10

70273878.review:
A beautiful and sweet story-based adventure.

Gameplay: 
Rakuen brings players into a familiar top-down view of its protagonist, using self-exploration to progress the story. Combat and party-management of traditional RPGs aren’t found here, however there are puzzles and mini-games well integrated into the story that allow for an enjoyable experience.

Story: 
A boy’s hospital stay soon becomes a journey through a magical parallel world, where he discovers the experiences of his fellow patients and new residents alike, while embracing his own path. 

Rakuen doesn’t hold its punches when presenting thought provoking themes, some being downright darker than the main premise. Yet each scenario is written beautifully to give the characters, as well as the player, a sense of hope. 

Music: 
Top tier. Incredibly crafted pieces that exert a plethora of emotions--joy, uneasiness, sadness, peace. From atmospheric to heart wrenching. Each piece is seemingly written specifically for each scene to convey the emotions of those moments. Vocally performed songs within scenes absolutely take the cake. 

Technical:
The game runs in 640x480 resolution, which can be expanded to full screen with alt+enter. Unfortunately, there are no other means of resizing when in windowed mode. There’s also a lack of an options menu to adjust in-game audio. Lack of d-pad usage while playing with a controller. Joystick inputs can be all over the place. (No run feature, but may have affected pacing)

Final Thoughts:
Personally, I recommend new players to go into Rakuen with as little information as possible. If you enjoy story-driven games, you’ll probably enjoy it. (A reason why the story section is short)

I happened to stumble upon one of Laura’s streams several months ago, and the performances had me smiling from ear to ear. Little did I know she composed a number of musical pieces for hit games, such as Plants vs. Zombies, World of Warcraft, To The Moon, and Deltarune. What made me stick around were the various music pieces she performed from her game along with the characters that appeared on screen (Leebles, Saitou-san, Sue/Puchi, and Bud emotes). I knew at some point I had to play Rakuen.

Story rich and filled with character development. Game is relatively simple, but some puzzles require big brain skills. 

This game is a rollercoaster of emotions. It’s got humor, quirky moments, cute characters, dark themes, hit-me-right-in-the-feels feels, atmospheric vibes, spooks.

I can’t say that I related to every story, but there was one word that I found myself steering towards as I reached the game’s conclusion: empathy. I was able to understand each character’s tale as it was presented and take on those emotions secondhand.

Other moments hit me like a brick. 

As someone that was introduced to the characters and music of Rakuen before playing the game, it was a joy to discover their origin. I probably can’t listen to “Build a Little World with Me” without getting emotional now…

Overall, I loved my experience with Rakuen. Thank you, Laura and co.

This is a game you play until the very end.

Not usually my kind of game but, I decided to give Rakuen a chance and try it out as the Artwork really appealed to me, and damn I am so glad i did. 
I usually don't go for the simple style games like this, but nothing stopped this game from sucking me into its world.
Honestly, i didn't know much about the game when i started, so the setting was a bit strange at the beginning. However, after atmosphere upon atmosphere, mystery after mystery, odd tasks here and there i was hooked.
There have been several moments in the game where i found myself tearing up due to the beautiful atmosphere created by the soundtrack and imagery; to chills running down my spine and my heart beating in sync with the one in-game as i walk along dimly lit corridors trying to understand the purpose of the envoy; are they here for me? I recommend this game 100% and it's definitely worth its full price.

Oh, hey, what's up, I couldn't see you through my OVERFLOWING TEARS,

I honestly cannot suggest this game enough, if you enjoy games heavy in storyline and puzzles and CUTENESSSss. I fkn love this game.

I would definitely just suggest exploring everything and everywhere that you can get close enough to try and interact with. I used my xbox controller, and the mechanics with it weren't GREAT, but certainly not an issue. 

I honestly cannot suggest this game enough, if you enjoy games heavy in storyline and puzzles and CUTENESSSss. I fkn love this game.

69889567.review:
I liked this game overall, but since there are so many reviews that focuses on the good parts, I'll share what I think this game is lacking. These are more prone when you are replaying it for the missing items.

- Walking without any running option or double click room-leaving. You can't fast travel and there is no option to make it easier for the player to travel somewhere they need to go. This becomes a problem because there are so many places available for you, yet you have to slow-walk everywhere. Especially when a lot of the rooms are made to have the longest road possible.
- You can't skip the scenes. It could be added as an option after finishing the first playthrough, at least.
- Not being able to skip is one thing, but you also can't let the scenes play themselves while you watch or do something else. It depends on you to keep the conversations going. This was the most annoying part for me at my 2nd playthrough.
- Mom's tips aren't much helpful in my opinion. She just repeats what you need to do which you can already see in your journal, but not how you need to do it. There are well-written guides so that's not much of a problem.

The art is so beautiful, the creatures are adorable, the worlds are creatively made, the story is sad but cute, some characters are really fun(ny) to talk to. Did I mention how gorgeous the artwork is? Seriously? It trully inspires me to create some fan artwork, and art in general for that matter.

It's a very peculiar game, but in a good way.
The story revolves around helping (well let's put that in between some quotes) 
My bad other me "helping" better? (much better thanks).
Anyways it's about "helping" some people in a hospital with their problems or coming to terms with them.

This game shines in it's music, it's simply phenomenal especially the solo parts.
Furthermore what got me good was the beautiful story and the ending.

The gameplay is very fetchquest like but I didn't mind as much because it's a nice break from all the "shoot the bad guy" or "finish building the big house".
Sometimes there is a switch to a dark undertone that legit creeped me out
But most of the time you walk around in a colourful environment that just exudes wholesomeness.

Sadly it isn't all good but the bad parts are minor.
Walking everywhere takes forever and gets rather boring halfway through.
The first two big parts has their darkish side "dungeon" then it skips two big parts and comes back at the very end to remind you it's still there.
Some of the things needed for the towel troupe achievement are easy to miss and if you don't track down enough money you wont be able to get them anymore.
The feeling that you helped people isn't really true because nothing really changed except them coming to terms with what happened [spoiler] his wife is still in coma and the girl still didn't get her dog back [/spoiler].

While there are more bad points than good points it seems like i'd still heavily recommend this game.
It's not that expansive and it gives heckin good bang for it's buck.
I'd get it even if it wasn't on sale and you should too.

69778549.review:
I'm someone who LOVES: story-rich, casual, atmospheric, comforting, relaxing, beautiful games. This is the PERFECT game for me. 
I don't really play games for skill or strategy, I'm just here for fun and good stories. 

I feel like this needs more publicity!!! Even though this is the absolute perfect game for me, I had never seen it until now when it was on sale. The three dollars and change are MORE THAN WORTH IT! I would have happily bought this game at full price. I'm not finished with the game by a long shot, still in the early stages. I started playing yesterday afternoon and I'm already in love.

Difficulty: This game is heartwarming, and the puzzles were fair. I haven't been playing games for very long, so sometimes I got stuck on what the game wanted me to accomplish and had to look up some guides, but for average players, you probably wouldn't get lost at all, it's quite intuitive. This game doesn't run on any time limits, save for some small moments. You're free to explore without worry, which I love. There were some moments where I actually got a little spooked and you have to run from bad spirits, but I'm also someone who got spooked in Stardew Valley and Undertale so. 

Side note, you can essentially play this game one-handed. The controls involve the arrow keys to move and enter/space keys to interact, which is really relaxing to play. I hardly ever had to reach for my mouse.

Art: The art style is gorgeous, and I wish all pixel graphics were as lovely as this. It really fits the story, and honestly is better than most other pixel graphics I've seen (adults and children are clearly distinguishable from each other lol). The music will give you feels, especially if you ever liked anime.

UPDATE: Finished it. Sobbed uncontrollably. One of my favorite games of all time.

Years ago I watched a youtuber finish the game from start to finish, and as of recent I decided to play the game myself. I'm happy to share that I still enjoyed myself a lot even though I knew of the major plot points and ending.

If you're a fan of both Ghibli films and RPG maker kind of games, then you're in for a treat. No doubt that there was a lot of love went into the development of Rakuen.

Charm - 10/10
Music - 10/10 (worth spending on the soundtrack)
Story - Heartaches/10
Puzzles - very forgiving/galaxy brain IQ

Without revealing too much, you play as a young boy in a hospital with his mother as a companion, in a quest to help other hospital residents' to reconnect with their dearly beloveds while saving a mystical land to have your wish granted. Each story will have you traverse between the hospital and the mystical forest to progress forward. As the game prioritizes story, there's zero combat involved in the game so you won't be distracted by the need of grinding. The characters are all charming and memorable till the end, in even footing with songs that would surely wash you over with feels and listen in repeat (while crying... a lot)

69593028.review:
Most games, you play them and leave them behind, but not Rakuen. This is a story that finds its way to stay within your heart.

Right from the start, Rakuen pulls you into the mysteries of the hospital through a series of fun and rewarding challenges. You venture into the parallel magical world of Rakuen and embark on an equally magical journey with each character. You listen to their longings and regrets, you help them find what’s been lost that was once so endearing, and you feel and cherish every bittersweet moment that is all too precious in this unforgiving world. 

In the end, you weave together a story that is both heartwarming and heartbreaking, with funny moments and beautiful music to accompany you on the way. More than a story through the lens of the characters, Rakuen is a personal journey that connects you to the once endearing feelings that you thought were long lost — feelings that are now here to stay.

69169754.review:
Rakuen is genuinely one of the best games I've played in years. Even though I've only played the first ten or so minutes, and I spent most of that time wandering around talking to people, I still feel like I accomplished a lot in that time.

The game is lovingly-crafted, with so much detail put into making the world as vibrant as possble. Almost everything is interactable, with the few things you can't interact with having an in-story reason, and I must admit that I spent one or two minutes in the main character's hospital bathroom just after the first cutscene where all I was doing was opening and shutting the toilet seat lid  (purely because I was so pleasantly surprised it was actually a thing I could do).

This is one of the most genuinely beautiful, well-made, well-composed, games that I have played for years and I think it's a game that everyone should play.

Buy Rakuen. Buy the soundtrack. You won't regret it, I promise.

Edit 19/06/20:
So... After having completed the game, I can honestly say it is one of the most beautiful, well-done, games I have ever played. Every character is nuanced and has their own unique backstory with their own problems, there's enough hints about the hospital's history that you can figure out what's going on without it being directly stated, and the bittersweet ending is just... god, it's perfect.
Everything from Sue's backstory on had me audibly breaking down in tears, and I couldn't be happier about that.
Copy-pasting from a comment I left on Twitter the day I finished: "Rakuen's ending is so poignant and bittersweet, while still hopeful, and the game's story as a whole is a welcome departure from more recent games where everyone gets a happy ending. You can't save everyone in the real life, and some tragedies are just inevitable. Relationships are messy, illnesses can devastate. But Rakuen will always be beautiful. Thank you, Laura. Thank you so much".

Since then I have watched other people play parts of the game. I have tried to describe it to a family member. I have listened to the soundtrack. Each time, without fail, tears well up. I just cannot get over this game.

Rakuen is an emotional experience. However, it is not tears from start to finish. Many parts are joyful or downright hilarious. The game has a quirky sense of humor that had me rolling at times, and incredible characters that will stay with you. You learn to care about these characters and what happens to them, which of course is the key to why the emotional parts are so powerful. Some people may be able to guess what will happen, but many plot points genuinely surprised me. Even for the times where I could correctly predict generally where the story was going, reaching that point was a beautiful journey - and never as clear cut as I expected.

This game deals with themes of loneliness, loss, and regret. As in life, not everything will turn out the way you may want. However, though loss and regret are themes throughout, I would not describe Rakuen as a tragedy. Rakuen is truly a story of love. Of redemption. And of hope.

I finished the story one week ago. But it will be a long time before Rakuen is finished with me.
