69050377.review:
Rakuen is a game about a Boy and his Mom, and how they help each other through a Very Long Day.  

It's a beautiful and very human experience, the kind that gives you reason to laugh as you dab at your leaky eyes.

If that sounds good, then go play Rakuen now!

As a more in-depth, spoiler-free review...

---

gameplay, story, music, visuals:

The writing is consistently charming and I found myself empathizing with main characters, rooting for the silly characters, and putting my hand over my mouth in an exhilarating  moment of "ahhh" insight more than once.

Both the pixel art and Laura's soundtrack are delightful and in the vein of classic 16-bit JRPGs.  There were times early in Rakuen where subtle details made me think, "...Chrono Trigger?" and it was gratifying to find other details later that made smile and say, "Chrono Trigger. :)"  

To be sure, Rakuen is very much its own game, but its style and presentation feel like a loving tribute to the games that likely inspired a younger Laura to want to make games herself one day.  

And in a way, this beautifully exemplifies the core theme of Rakuen – finding inspiration and hope in the people who love us, and passing those on to others so they can do the same.

---

themes:

Rakuen might be described as "sad" or "a tear-jerker," but everything is balanced.  The story, music, character dialogue, and humor all come together to make Rakuen feel like a friend who wants you to see the best in yourself.

It's a cold night, but Rakuen keeps you company, holding your hand and telling you a story for 10 hours until the sun comes back up.  You can feel it gently squeeze back, as though to say, "it's okay to be scared; I'm a little scared too, but we're gonna make it through this."

Reading the description of "Jump" from Rakuen's OST on Laura's bandcamp page, going backwards through multiple years of devlogs posts on projectrakuen – Rakuen becomes less of a game and more an extension of the person who created it.

---

Rakuen and me:

Rakuen is the realization of every RPG Maker game I'd wanted to make between 2005 and 2011 when I was active on forums of that time.  

RMXP is the reason I started tinkering with programming and dabbling in arranging music, so it was heartwarming to see familiar names in the credits, and truly inspiring to understand that someone had the perseverance to see this kind of game through to completion.

Promotional art in an October 2013 news post on projectrakuen shows that the characters, story, and world were already quite developed by then, which makes the implied effort leading to the eventual May 2017 release all the more palpable.

By late 2006, I'd been hanging out at creationasylum long enough to see too many projects organize and make progress, only to fall apart within months. The creeping insight into *how much work would be needed* to make a game was discouraging. Seeing project after project drift apart was discouraging.

I'd proposed making a "short story game" that would last "no more than two hours" and started at least three. Each fell apart; none saw release.  It turns out that games are really difficult and consuming to make. :)

So, in a way, it's relieving to read Laura write in 2016:

"Rakuen went through 3 iterations… at first it was a crafting game, then it became a jrpg, and now it’s an adventure game with point-and-click/room escape style puzzles, Zelda-like dungeons, and some mysteries that revolve around having to talk with the characters."

Playing it, experiencing it, learning more about it – Rakuen is a triumph.  It tells a story about how we can find hope in others, and then leads by example, suggesting to me that it *is* possible to make a game that tells a story from the heart.

Thank you, Laura, for having the passion to see Rakuen through to release.

68809323.review:
Ok, two ways about this:

If this game was intended for young (as in "child" audiences) it gets a pass on many of my gripes. The target audience was not readily apparent from the store description.

If it wasn't meant for children... Oh boy.

Now, it DOES get better. But the first half of the game is a TREMENDOUS slog through mind-numbingly boring gameplay and ham-fisted exposition bombs. It has all the bearings of someone without any experience or skill in either game design or writing. Everything is explained to the minutest detail, and repeated - over, and OVER, again! 

The "adventuring" is strictly linear, with zones beyond one or two blocked off by plot markers.
The "puzzles" can't be really called such, as none of them require any thought whatsoever, with the solutions easily visible either in the very same room(!) or the one right next to it. Be ready for a lot of "pick up item" -> "use item."
The "story" gets delivered as a pile of human interest stories that beg for your empathy, yet delivered in such a flat, superficial way, that it is extremely hard to get attached to any of the characters. There's a complete lack of subtext, suspense, or mystery. Everything is right there on the tin. 

As said, it gets better towards the end, but part of why is less than flattering - it's because the game kind of forgets it's a game. Instead it showers you with extensive in-game cutscenes, with even the illusion of interactivity gone. And this section of the game was a passable story I could listen to while sipping on my tea. But gamewise, there was nothing there.

All in all, the whole story might've been better presented in a visual novel format, unburdened with the trite and uninspired, even forced, "game" elements. Even then, the writing would have required some heavy work to hold my interest, and patience. When the writer stops to explain even their puns - then it's either a game for children, or by one.

68797477.review: I loved this game so much. Seriously, set aside a day or two of your time and play through Rakuen. It'll be worth it.

67753072.review:
Rakuen is an emotional RPG maker story game about a hospitalized boy who goes on an imagined adventure with his Mom inspired by his book Rakuen to ask the Guardian of the Forest to grant him a wish. To receive this wish the boy is sent on a quest in the fantasy world of Morizora's forest to find out the forgotten song and wake up the Guardian. On this journey he helps out the residents of the Leeble village as well as the patients in his hospital. Featuring a runaway couple with unapproved love by their parents, a young girl breaking her promise, a grumpy old man looking for his music box and a man who lost his memory.

The game runs in a 640x480 resolution which can be stretched to fullscreen with alt + enter. The gameplay is an interactive story with puzzle solving and the controls are what you would expect from most RPG maker games with a hint system (asking Mom in the menu). This is Laura Shigihara's take on creating an adventure game, so you can expect good songs like in To the Moon and Finding Paradise.

For achievement hunters:
There are missables and collectables which are guided in the steam forums.

66948244.review:
pros
- interesting concept/ story. 
- ost has a couple of lovely songs, that i'll return to.
- A lot of fun dialogue and good character moments.
- The story explores many serious real life topics in a way that feels accessible to everyone. This is the main reason why I'd recommend this game.
- The ending was extremely touching and I did get a bit misty eyed.

cons
- The game play was weak, a lot of fetch quests and escape room style problem solving. Its a bit of a slog. Thankfully about half way through these aspects of the game practically vanish in favour of more cut scenes...which is good, I guess?
- A handful of character designs were so goofy, they actually spoilt certain scenes for me later on.
- This game *really* wants you to cry and get emotional- it does everything in its power to do that, for me it only worked 50% of the time, which made the other 50% a little awkward to sit through. 

At the end of the day I don't regret playing Rakuen, parts of it will stick with me for a long time. I think this was would an amazing game to play alongside children- to teach them about some of the difficult topics the story covers.

64426402.review:
I bought this game a while back, but put off playing it until now. Turns out that was a big mistake.

As an rpg maker game of this type, Rakuen is heavily focused on story, exploration, and puzzles. You, the unnamed boy, travel back and forth between the hospital and mystical world of Rakuen many times throughout the game, meeting lots of different characters and collecting items on the way. And, thankfully, this game's greatest strength is its story and characters.

Rakuen is lighthearted and colorful while still taking on some really serious topics, including aging, sickness, and death. The wholesome approach makes it easy to connect with the characters and their lives, but when it gets down to the important parts, there are enough heart-wrenching moments to put this up with the saddest rpg maker games out there. What it lacks in exciting gameplay (it's mostly just collecting items and talking to people), it makes up for in its charm, polish, and overwhelmingly good messages and intent.

There are only 2 things I didn't like - 1: no dash button (but there is a fan patch that can fix this), and 2: the singing. I think the singing just makes things awkward and the game would've been fine without it, but characters only do it a few times. Other than that, the music, visuals, and UI compliment the rest of the game, and at 7 hours Rakuen was a pretty good length too.

Definitely one of the best story-driven rpg maker games out there. There are too many great moments to pass it up.

64392142.review:
EDIT: FINISH WATCHING THE CREDITS UNTIL THE END!! IT WILL MAKE YOUR HEART SO HAPPY. I finished the game...it seemed like the closer to the end it got, the sadder it got, my heart feels so broken after the entire Sue story, then that adorable dream the boy had with her, just for him to wake up and tragedy hits...I still feel no different towards the game than I did in my first review, as sad and emotion wrenching as this game is, Ill repeat what I said before. IT'S SUCH A SPECIAL GAME <3 Please make more like this. 

This game is so special. 
Be ready to dive into a world of emotions, and that might involve some crying.
For anyone that struggles with depression, anxiety, or any other mental illness that might make you feel less than good enough, or even for those who don't suffer with mental illness but you're in a dark place.
This game will almost be like a therapy session for you every time you play it.

The Pixel work is fantastic as well.
The music is just...I mean that alone makes me emotional because of how absolutely amazing it is. 
You really get connected with all the characters as well....which scares me because I have a feeling not all the characters stories will end how I hope. 

I will admit Some parts are a little scary for me, but its mainly cause the music gets so eerie LOL. So I've learned to just mute it at those parts.

I don't think I'm super far into the game yet, but I can't wait to keep playing, it's such a treat!
Also helps a lot that there's a walkthrough guide online, because some parts I just have NO idea what to do.

Super excited to keep playing and even more excited to say I finished it. 
In all honesty it's definitely top 3 of my favorite games ever made.

[h1] Rakuen - [i] An adventurous non-combat RPG & heartbreaker [/i] [/h1]

[b] - Story rich ✔ - [/b]
[i] It's a creative story filled with more stories within and a lot of fantasy! You have a little boy in the hospital and a mom taking off of work for some days to spend time with him. During his time in the hospital, the boy gets to know the other patients on his station, their personalities and their stories. [/i]
[b] - Interesting ✔ - [/b]
[i] The boy and his mother have a favorite book about a forest guardian that can grant you a wish. They set off to this magical forest in the world of Rakuen, where they meet the counterparts of the patients on the station living in a forest village. [/i]
[b] - Emotional ✔ - [/b]
[i] In this magical forest village, on the way to find Rakuen, the forest guardian, the boy and his mother solve puzzles and help the inhabitants and ultimately his neighbours in the hospital, as his actions affect each counterpart of a character. You have the story of the boy himself and his family. Additionally you encounter the stories of the other characters in the hospital, each and every one of them heartwarming. [/i] 
[b] - Atmospheric ✔ - [/b]
[i] You will not be disappointed by this game. The music (partially voiced), the stories, the characters, the main story, it will all embrace you. [/i]
[b] - Beautiful soundtrack  ✔ - [/b]
[i] The soundtrack is purely touching and wonderful. It fits perfectly into the game, as it accompanies you. A delight! [/i]
[b] - All around heartwarming and heartbreaking. ✔ - [/b]
[i] This game will get you to tears, or very close to it. It will definitely touch your heart. [/i]

[b] PS. Maybe you don't mind or enjoy slow paced walking, while you explore games. If you don't enjoy, check the guides. A kind soul has uploaded a sprinting patch. It helps a lot! Thank you to the creator! [/b]

61869876.review: This game is wonderful. The characters are wonderfully written, and the soundtrack is super-cohesive and builds upon itself with each new area in the game. I even like the cheesy, but cute songs you hear after you figure out each patients story. The art style is gorgeous and very detailed. The only problems I had with the game is that the only characters who had a really long puzzle section in the darker parts of the world where Tony, Gemma, and the Boy. I feel like Kisaburo and Sue got a little cheated in that respect. I think if the long puzzle sections of Gemma and Tony were paired down a bit, then Sue and Kisaburo's stories could be expanded upon. Also, the revelation of Uma's identity felt like a little bit of an afterthought, but I mostly enjoyed him as a character and how he randomly showed up throughout the story. Overall, I would highly recommend this game and kudos to Laura Shigihara for creating an amazing experience as a first-time game developer. Bravo. I hope to see more from her in the future.

If I had to give a con, it would be that there's a difference in story arc formats throughout the game - for example, I remember that one of the first story arcs was over an hour of interactive exploration, investigation, and puzzling; while one of the final story arcs felt like a half-hour movie. I recommend this game greatly if you want to try a story-driven game. Or even if you're just thinking about trying a story-driven game, if you want a break from action-driven games.

60802702.review:
I don't like the terms "heartbreakers" or "tearjerkers." They kind of sell a piece of media as being about making you feel sad enough to cry.

And while Rakuen might end up making you cry, it's about more than making you merely feel heartbroken. It takes you through the gamut of emotions and experiences: love, hope, fear, hurt, sadness...

But mostly it's a game about love, in a way that most games aren't. Even other games about family relationships rarely nail it like Rakuen does. I hope you play it, because it's not just "good for a game" at tackling its themes. It's just plain special.

59698616.review:
This was a really wonderful game. The story, music, and art were all excellent and clearly made with love and care. If you enjoy story-heavy RPGs, you will certainly like this game as well. If you've played other RPG-maker story games like To The Moon, I would say Rakuen has a little more "video game" to it than those games. The game is still non-combat and story-driven, but has  puzzles, hidden areas, and additional secrets that reward your exploration. And while you might not fight monsters head-on, you certainly have to handle dangerous situations at times. It's definitely a game and not just clicking through the text. I really enjoyed that and had a good time finding all the secrets and unlocking extra achievements. 

I don't want to spoil any of the story, but needless to say, it is meaningful and poignant. It is a journey worth taking. 

And as a final note, the music is fantastic! I highly recommend bundling in the soundtrack if you pick up the game. Laura Shigihara does an amazing job and I've been listening to the soundtrack a ton since I finished the game. It has even inspired me to try playing some of the music myself!

59694027.review:
Beautiful game, making people want to cry for ages. One character's arc had me and my girlfriend crying. Rakuen is one of those games that stick with you well after playing it. There aren't many games that stick with me, I can name one other game that wholly changed my entire perspective on life.

This game will make you cry. Sorrow filled with joy, all in the same bag. Laura's composition just makes it all the better. In fact that was one of the biggest purchasing decisions. Laura's music I have found to always sound wonderful, So if you are grabbing the game, Grab the soundtrack if you really enjoy listening to it.

All in all, this still stands as one of my favorite games, and will continue to be one of the games that has touched my life. Thank you Laura, Your music has always been something that has drove me to continue my passion for my own music creation.

59533640.review:
[h1] This game is beautiful, plain and simple. [/h1]

I want to open with this: I played and finished Rakuen about 7 months ago. It's rare that a day passes that I don't think about it at least in passing. If you like story-centric games, this is an absolute must-have. You won't be sorry, and that is a promise!

While this is an RPGMaker game, don't let that put you off. With a beautiful soundtrack worthy of listening to on its own, unique and detailed sprite work, and beautiful close-ups of characters during dialogue, the game simply oozes charm and personality with every line of text and every person you meet.

This game also goes out to all the bleeding hearts in the world. To those who still have empathy for the strangers you meet in your daily life. I don't want to say anything about the plot, but I just want to say this game is a true testament to what it looks like to value love and kindness above all else. This is art. It's a work of fiction, but there are so many tangible things you can take away from it, and I really hope it touches your heart like it did mine.

P.S.: If you get the game, remember this: you can go down wells. You know, the kind that fetch water. Thank me later.

58516409.review:
Rakuen is a somber, heartfelt tearjerker of a story. This comes as no surprise given the creator's involvement in To The Moon, one of the best and most depressing RPG Maker games in history. The only issues I have with Rakuen are some pacing and tonal issues, which are admittedly more profound in the game's first half. If you can get past that (and a few frustrating puzzle sections), the game grows into a much more human and touching narrative. 

The fantasy world is well done and very cutesy. There are lots of memorable characters and moments throughout. For me, the game started to drag a little around the 2nd and 3rd chapter, although the tone and atmosphere did help carry these slower and less interesting story bits. It picks up again in the 4th and 5th chapter and will probably evoke emotions in all but the least-feeling of people. 

Rakuen is a story about loss and coping, and it's a potent one at that. It suffers from some intermittent "game problems" such as pacing, tone and weak puzzles but it's Shigihara's first title and those teething issues can be expected, especially given RPG Maker's limitations. It's currently on sale for $5 USD and it's a great purchase for that price if you like adventure games with melancholy stories.

57410244.review:
Rakuen is a special game. It really is, now I know chances are if you are looking at this game you are doing so because you likely love "To the Moon" or "Finding Paradise" and are looking for a similar experience. 

Look, if To the Moon and Finding Paradise were really solid movies- then this would be the same as a TV show in similar style. It offers the same style of emotion hitting storyline- but spaces it out with a larger amount of "Slice of life" style positivity and adventures! Unlike the previous games I mentioned in this review- Rauken offers a series of basic but endearing puzzles to go along with the hard hitting emotions. Play through what I would equate to one "episode" with each of the major residents in a hospital as you do your best to help yourself (and them) cope with their stay. 

Not every story in Rakuen made me cry- but each one offered its own level of emotionality- and even within an entire game dedicated to presenting a series of interesting and often hard hitting stories I still found the game hitting me at unexpected times.

Look- Laura has done something really special here- she has created a beautiful world with charming and endearing characters and you'd be doing yourself a major disservice if you skipped this one.

57349121.review: One of the most beautiful and heartwarming games I have ever played.

57330389.review:
TLDR: Rakuen reminded me why gaming can be such a powerful medium for good. With a design that is both simple and profound, this combat-free story-driven RPG delivers a beautiful, heart-breaking, and life-affirming experience.

GAMEPLAY/STORY (spoiler-free): The gameplay is designed around the narrative. In general, it's a top-down RPG, but there is no combat system, experience, or party management. Don't get me wrong, there is definitely conflict in-game, but it is masterfully woven in through the story itself and the minigames and puzzles scattered throughout. While the puzzles are relatively simple, they feel right in the game, and there were only a couple very minor moments where I felt lost or wasn't sure how they related to the game as a whole.

The game world is full of detail, and there are lots of hints alluding to missing pieces in the game environment that are later revealed more clearly throughout the game. Definitely pay attention to the little things here! In my playthrough there were a few key moments where those pieces just fit together and I had realizations, often chilling ones, into what may be happening next. The timing of these hints seemed to fit well with the general plot discovery timeline. The observant may figure out some key plot points, but not so far ahead of the actual reveals that they feel like heavy-handed foreshadowing or take away from the payoff. Even if you do see a few twists coming, there are still plenty of key surprises around the actual characters and the reveals of their experiences. I found the storyline satisfying and complete overall. It left me with the right amount of resolution, questions, and feelings, to make Rakuen something I am unlikely to ever forget. Many people will be able to relate to the tragedy and the hope in their own ways. Despite not sharing the exact experiences of the characters there were a few very emotional moments that hit me due to personal experiences, and I imagine many if not most players have similar stories. I also felt connected to the protagonists and did feel enough of a sense of agency despite the linear nature of the story.

Without delving into any spoilers, the game is separated into a handful of scenarios around helping different characters in a hospital, going between 'our world' and a vibrant, fanciful parallel world. Throughout this you learn about the characters' pasts, as well as what has happened recently in the world around you. There is a tension between what the twin protagonists (the boy and his mother) know of the recent past and what you as the player don't know. As this resolves, it feeds into the overall storyline, leading to a stunning finish. While overall Rakuen is a rather linear game, this seemed appropriate to the subject material and the storytelling, and helped to drive the pacing. There are additional achievements and side quests in-game that add additional fun and flavor, but are not required to get the impact of the core storyline. As I was livestreaming this, I did not complete all the side material in my first playthrough. I do plan on going back and 100%ing Rakuen on my own because I want to see all the little gems that I might have missed.

MUSIC: Being a game by Laura Shigihara, the music is of course S-tier. There are several vocally performed songs in-game during cutscenes, and motifs throughout the background music. "Build A Little World With Me" is an unforgettable track.

CONCLUSION:
 I was fortunate enough to be able to livestream this on Twitch with Laura Shigihara in chat seeing large portions of the playthrough. (However, I was not in any way compelled or compensated to play the game or to write a review.) She exemplifies how much love was poured into the creation of this game, especially through her involvement with the gaming community playing Rakuen. She takes genuine joy of seeing peoples' unique reactions to the game, and I was also able to get many unique tidbits about the development and the game in general. This is the kind of community-building that exemplifies what can be done with indie games. Between Rakuen, Laura's vast catalog of game music, her music stream on Twitch, and her genuine care for the gaming community, I'm definitely going to be looking forward enthusiastically to anything she releases next.

Overall, this is a wonderful story-driven RPG that will make you laugh, cry, and think. The only thing I would change about it would be to add a steam achievement around filling up every sink in the game. ;) If you are looking for a deeply emotional experience that overflows with magic and hope even while diving head-on into the gritty and heart-breaking challenges of life and loss, play Rakuen. Would recommend without reservation.

56213862.review:
You get to play as a dog. 'Nuff said.

But seriously though, this is one of those kinds of games that I consider as an "experience". If you know and love the anime "Violet Evergarden", then you should be pretty familiar with Rakuen and it's style of storytelling. Rakuen really shines in its various vignettes with the patients of the hospital, who are really great characters in it of themselves. The stories feel natural in the ways they're told (apart from a few plot holes I've noticed but that's more of a nitpick lol), and they really did a good job in making you sympathize with them, no matter if you've had a personal experience with hospitals, diseases, and the like.

Though I do understand that this is probably not for everyone. There is ABSOLUTELY no combat here. The most stressful times gameplay-wise are the timed sequences and obstacle-dodging events that are pretty standard in many RPG Maker works. There is no in-game Settings so you're stuck with some pretty awkward controls (Arrowkeys for movement, esc for opening the menu, no option for WASD movement x.x) but you'll get used to it. 

Overall, this is a really important game for us to experience. This game just shows the power of kindness and love in the face of hopelessness and despair, and I believe that's an important message that we need to see for ourselves in our world today.

And you get to play as a dog. tenouttaten

56098768.review: I've not completed the game yet, but what I've seen I've really loved. The game just really draws you in. I've only just got it today, and I've been playing nonstop (My playtime at this point is 5 hours) When I first started playing I admit I wasn't too impressed, I thought the dialog and the plot that I had seen thus-far to be a bit childish. But the more I played the less that my first opinion stood firm. While the beginning seems a bit childish, the rest of the game-while still cute-has a very ominous and. at some points, creepy tone.  Even when you are talking to cute NPCs and doing friendly quests for the townsfolk, there is this 'what if' feeling hovering over your head. Even though I am not even close to finishing, I can't shake the feeling that the ending won't be all that happy. This just makes the game even more addicting, and I want to be proven wrong so bad. The game also does a really good job with addressing real life issues, which is something I wasn't expecting but really like. I was expecting this game to be a cutsie 5 minute 'when you have nothing better to do' game, but it really isn't and I recommend this 100%

Do you ever have those games/books/movies where once you finish, you don't know what to do with yourself? 

Rakuen is that game. 

You play through the game, the art and music is beautiful, and the characters are quirky and loveable. It's at the end of the game when you realize what it's all about, what the game was always leading you towards, even if you didn't know it. I identified strongly with one of the characters as my father struggled with the same illness, but to my surprise, it wasn't his story that moved me to tears, it was all of the others. I already knew what it was like to deal with my father's story, but it was being exposed to the raw emotions of everyone else's that moved me.

You'll regret not playing this game.

10/10 and easily one of my favorite games ever.

55238796.review:
Rakuen is atmospheric & magical in its artistry, endearing in its characters & narrative, thought-provoking in its treatment of grief, illness, & relationships. First & foremost, Rakuen respectfully sympathizes without pity, & imo, supports the complex feelings & needs of those suffering from terminal illness. I admire how gracefully this game negates stigmas surrounding illness/old age/health needs by centering spiritual & bodily healing through "unlocking" accessible environments, support systems, & accommodations... That's what I took from the puzzle elements that unlock new tools, gifts, memories, & doors for exploration & closure. 

What may be overlooked is the significance of tragedy stemming from real-world events such as the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake, tsunami, & Fukushima nuclear plant disaster. The narrative not only cares for the spiritual wellness of the characters, but also of the natural & structural environments, which are highly interconnected. I do wish this connection was made more explicit in the "real" world rather than only in Morizora's fantasy realm. While the game plays into some tropes about maintaining "hope" & resisting submersion in anger/grief, I think there's some redemption in treating suffering on both individual & systemic levels. 

Definitely worth your time if you're patient to appreciate the enchanting atmosphere, become intimate with characters, remain thoughtful about the story that isn't always straightforward/single-note, & get deep into bittersweet feels.

55012064.review: A very lovely game that I spammed through. It is simple in that most of the puzzle/challenge comes from figuring out where to go to do certain things. I didn't feel that this detracts from the gameplay since the game is more focused on the characters and the mood than challenge. I view the other world as either taking place place inside the boy's mind or at least as a metaphor for his outlook on the world, so it fits that it would be challenging on a kid's level. The gameplay is simple, but the story is layered. As I said, it is a depiction of the boy's mind and pieces each character's backstory/situation together as you go. Parts of it have to be interrupted rather than being stated directly, which I found fitting since, again you are seeing things from the boy's perspective even in these memories. It is emotional. I read reviews that mentioned crying over this game before I started, so I kept waiting for it to happen. After the first character arc, I was thinking "okay, I can see why you might cry but I probably won't." Well then I was this close to tearing up at the second character arc.Then at the final last hour stretch I cried 4 times. Of course, the game throws humor in there as well. I love Sugar Baby. Speaking of creatures, they are so silly, cute, and original. Even the pink bear's sprite is just adorable (I forget her name and don't want to say her relation even though it is a minor spoiler). I played this game a while ago, but it was quite possibly the most beautiful game I've ever played. 

The story is sweet, incredibly moving, and hits you like a punch in the gut later on in the game. I'm usually more reserved with my emotions, but the final scene really made me shed a tear.

54651994.review:
'Rakuen' spares no expense in creating a meaningful and even profound gameplay experience. With a story so rich in depth and a setting so vast in scope, I am sure this will be the best game I will ever play. I don't mean that it is as thrilling as, say, an FPS game or a horror RPG, or that the production quality will blow your screen and speakers away. It is not that kind of game. It offers what most entertaining games do not: a sincere story told with love and detail, and you can feel it in every pixel from the beginning. If I have to summarize the game, it is like a great Disney movie in the form of an interactive visual novel.

There is so much effort put into the art of the game that even after I explored most of the maps, I still managed to feel lost because no two maps have the same layout, and that is a good thing. With so much detail put into the design of the maps and the vast amount of NPCs and interactive objects, it made me feel like I was there, living in that world. The design and colours are so surreal that it brings a whole new level of beauty to 2D pixel art. Many times I could not believe the level of detail that went into the map designs. I could go on and on, but nothing anyone can say will be better than experiencing it for real. 

The elevating element of the game is the MUSIC. Oh boy. The music of 'Rakuen' cannot be simply referred to as BGM. It is so beautifully composed and well crafted that it transcends the barrier of in-game music to a legitimate listening experience. Many game soundtracks really sound like a game soundtrack (with heavy/suspenseful beats signifying an intense moment, or a repetitive tune that is really just a background filler), but this game's soundtrack sounds like it was created for an album release possibly titled 'Relaxing Music from Nature and Beyond' and then licensed for use in this game. The music is so rich with so many elements that it just BEGS to be experienced in the highest quality possible, and even better, in 5.1 surround (it doesn't exist, sadly). 

My only real issue with the gameplay (which is really only just a trifle), is that many of the puzzles/challenges are not necessarily related to the story. They appear to be present as mere obstacles rather than to provide additional context or thematic enhancements to the story. However, one has to be reminded that they are playing this game (mostly) through the eyes of a child on an adventure and without spoiling anything, I would say let your imagination provide context to where there seem none and it will be a lot more fun. And also, I wish the character could move just a little bit faster because some maps are really huge and it felt like quite a chore at times to move from place to place.

Do not let my issues as stated above prevent you from experiencing this unbelievably wholesome game. Its sincere depiction of feelings and truth separates it from the bulk, and its never-ending creativity in character designs and stories make it an experience impossible to forget. It is heartwarming and tear-jerking even for some (or most). The main characters are extremely lovable as well as some of the side characters. The game developers deserve every praise for the extra mile taken to provide an extremely meaningful experience that is 'Rakuen', and what a rakuen (paradise) it is!

54294068.review:
Rakuen is an emotional journey following a hospitalised little boy and his mother exploring a beautiful fantasy world filled with delightful creatures and environments. Along the way, you meet a variety of different characters both in the hospital and in the fantasy world and learn their complex backstories. The game does a great job of bringing up important topics and truths about the world that often aren't talked about a lot. 

Featuring a phenomenally touching soundtrack, beautifully designed visuals, and creatively well thought-out puzzles — Rakuen is diligently crafted with so many details that make it an unforgettable experience. The end result is a bittersweet narrative that balances being hopeful, heart-rending, humorous, and heavy very well.

I definitely recommend it if you enjoy emotional and character-rich stories. [b] Bring tissues though. [/b]

[spoiler] "Build A Little World With Me" is now one of my favourite songs ever. [/spoiler]

SILA BERRY SPECIAL TEA / 10

P.S. The game's creator, Laura Shigihara, is so wonderfully talented and inspiring!

54222094.review:
Para un juego como este lo único que puedo decir es…sumamente impresionante. 

Colocar un apartado de pros y contras sería absurdo, pues en Rakuen salvo un detalle, todo son cosas positivas. 
Una música hermosa, acompañada de una historia que, en apariencia, es infantil, sin embargo, si eres adulto, pronto te enteras que todo lo contrario, es una historia sobre la vida, sobre las decisiones difíciles, sobre la soledad y la esperanza. Por momentos poético, que te hace reflexiones; en otros divertido, para sacarte una sonrisa y, en otros, tan triste que sin duda podrías acabar llorando ante una escena. 

Diálogos interesantes, personajes sumamente carismático que hace que te preocupes por ellos y por averiguar sus historias, un protagonista que es de lo mejor que he visto en décadas en este mundillo y una mecánica de juego sencilla pero armoniosa. 
Este es un RPG de la vieja escuela que te hará recordar muchos de los grandes iconos y, aunque carece de combate, te aseguro que no te hará falta, pues Rakuen se trata de enfrentar una historia dura y, que rumbo al final, tienes miedo de que pase aquello que te imaginas (pues el juego, con algo de atención, te advierte lo que se viene). 

Su durabilidad para ser un juego no muy popular es muy alta, por no decir que tiene secretillos que deberás descubrir con algo de exploración. Juegos como este, me hacen pensar qué podría hacer esta gente con un alto presupuesto…sin duda, seguro estaríamos ante el renacimiento de los RPG en 2D. 

Una compra obligada para todo aquel amante de historias emotivas, congruentes y sobre todo, que hablen del ser humano y la vida misma. 

NOTA: 10

54205341.review:
One thing I really like about this game is that it shows the value of different perspectives in gaming. How often do you get to play the protagonist with their mother, together, getting an equal dose of both of their struggles? You get to see a wide variety of perspectives in each of the mini stories, too - it isn't just about the afflicted, but the people closest to them. 

Mechanically, there's nothing here you won't have seen before, but I think the diversity of perspective is something you won't find in that many games. Be warned: it is a deceptively heavy game, though the cartoonish/childlike perspective softens some of the edges.

54146053.review:
This is an exceptional narrative game.

The story and music in particular are excellent, and really shine in this format. The gameplay is pretty straightforward (which suits the style of game). There is some depth to be found in the form of puzzle-solving -- but these puzzles are very well integrated to the story and won't hinder anyone too much.

The artwork is decent, solid pixelart, comparable to the likes of FF6 or Secret of Mana, with some really excellent and standout sprite work on creatures / characters, and little custom animations that give the cutscenes more strength. 

The main cast of characters are very well realised and believable, and as you play Rakuen you learn a lot about them. With this, the story opens up to explore many difficult themes in a super intelligent and delicate way.

Overall I would compare playing this to the experience of reading a really good, heartfelt book.

54139814.review:
I'd first read comments that showed it was an emotional journey, and I do enjoy a story that gets to your heart, so I gave it a shot, but was surprised to see how much impact it really had. Cried so much I had to bring around a towel because a handkerchief would be a sogging mess after each session. Each section of the story held such great pacing and weight that I was looking forward to the next one, even though I was dehydrated after the last. Really well done. 

I did find that some parts of the game were tedious when I only wanted to progress the story, like collection tasks or backtracking through what are admittedly small worlds, which is probably for the best, but the story/music/heart that is felt through any time in this game was well worth it.

This is very much recommended if you're a sap like me. There are too many points in the story that make you reevaluate some things in your own life, which is a profound difference from many other games out there.

Bottom line: Loved It.

53941931.review:
This game is fantastic. 9/10. Ya boi cried real good. So let's start this review.

There is no combat and I think it worked great for the game. All it is is walking around and talking to people and interacting with objects and solving puzzles. There's a lot you have to interact with to solve some of the puzzles which was annoying at first, but I began to enjoy it as every character you talked to was fun, and you found out things about the world through interacting with other objects. The soundtrack is also great. I know Laura Shigihara did songs for the game "To The Moon" and also the "Plants vs Zombies" soundtrack. I had just coincidentally played plants vs zombies very recently before playing this and in some of the songs you can see the similarity in the sound since they're both done by Laura. So that being said it hit all the playful and emotional spots it needed to hit. There are songs with vocals as well that are just so cute and heart warming. As said before all the characters are a lot of fun as well. I really really liked the art. It was very bright and the characters full of personality and life along with nice high quality portraits of important characters when you talk to them like the boy or his mom. Who are both amazing characters.

Now onto the story. Hot dang it made me feel some things. I'm not sure if anyone will relate to this feeling, but after watching a really good slice of anime even though you cried, which I'll reiterate that I definitly cried, you still feel really good after like you've been cleansed. After playing I just sorta floated around my house thinking about it cause it gave me such a light and really happy feeling like I wanted to help people, since that's what you do the entire game. It made me feel sympathy and compassion for others and an overall warm feeling. I've discussed this feeling with a friend about feeling like that after a really good slice of life anime and they know what I'm talking about so if you do I hope this part at least sells it. Anywho, the story is you're a kid in a hospital who opens a door to a different world that takes place in his favorite book, Rakuen, and he's trying to get the guardian of the forest to grant him a wish. You go through a journey of seeing the stories of others and helping them. Covers lots of themes like racism and parenting and just a lot of love. I'm not one for forced positivity, but I accepted the childish aura of the game and that made me enjoy it a lot.

I've rambled enough. In summary, buy the game. It's fun, great story, great characters, great art, great soundtrack, will make you cry and feel emotions. 9/10.

53605212.review:
This game plays like a children's storybook, both in that it's literally a children's storybook, and that it's extremely linear and predictable. But sometimes that's what you want. Depending on your age and life experience, this game will mean more or less to you. I found it sweet, but not quite a tearjerker.

Controls are eh, walking is painfully slow & collisions are awkward (see: RPG Maker), backtracking is almost always a pain, level design is all over the place. Characters are kind of unbalanced - some people who seem like they should be very important (they have portraits!) are barely spoken to, while some of the bit characters get way more time. I feel like I know Peanut Chew Shift Leader and Li'l Bud way more than Cora and Danielle. It almost seems mean to critique the mechanics of something like this, especially when it's in RPG Maker and has RPGM's limitations, but I'm throwing this in there so that anyone similar to me at least isn't surprised by the wonky bits.

Basically: I don't mind that I played this, but I don't think I'd recommend it to friends. It's alright. :)

53602290.review: Rakuen is an experience. Narratives woven throughout a very interesting and adorable world, coming together in an emotional climax. There will be laughs, there will be tears, but most of all there will be characters and music that will impact you long after you finish the game. This is a light puzzle solving game, but at it's core it's a narrative adventure game. If you are looking for a narrative adventure game, similar to Finding Paradise and To the Moon (both of which Laura Shigihara did music for), then I highly recommend picking it up.

This little game utterly blew away my expectations. 

The pixel graphics are bright, pretty, and utterly charming.

The music is absolutely beautiful and I immediately had to purchase the soundtrack after completing the game. You can absolutely tell the creator is a musician- there's some serious passion in every song. 

But what really blew me away was the story and characters. Every little chapter was heartfelt and thoughtful, even making room for some humour here and there. 

And I can tell you; I have NEVER cried so hard at a videogame. The ending left me an utter wreck. It just goes to show how impactful Rakuen is when it's all put together. 

I absolutely recommend giving this a shot if you're a fan of story and character-driven games. You won't be disappointed.

52165047.review:
Rakuen is beautiful, with an entrancing story of a kid in the hospital helping others and learning more about life. It's very wholesome, and very sad by the end. The story is all about learning empathy for others, and acceptance of yourself and your circumstances. There is a fantasy component which seems to be more metaphorical, but it's open to interpretation.

It was made in RPG maker but there is no combat or character building, just lots of dialog, item collection and some minor puzzles. It feels very relaxing to play for the most part, though there are a few more tense sections. I thought the characters were quite well done, and I was continually interested to see what would happen next.

If an emotional game of this nature seems appealing, this is a great example, and is worth your time. Recommended!

51891787.review:
Benefits
* appealing visual style
* magical world with cute creatures is fun to explore
* nice music
* an attempt to tell an emotionally involving story

Flaws
* inconsistent tone
* subtle, like a punch in the face
* involves a lot of backtracking during solving puzzles or exploring the magical world
* rushed during the second half of the third quest - from this point on toward the end the game basically plays itself
* hardly anything is explained in the end


Too bad, there is no way to give this game a neutral review - it has to be either a thumbs up or thumbs down. Well, it's a nice game overall, so it feels bad to give it a negative review, but it has issues and is rough around the edges. It tries to be both tragic and whimsical (I understand that that devs wanted to create a contrast this way) and falls short on both ways, being not really either of these. To add devs' desire to make a game a bit horror-ish and their creation became even more inconsistent in its tone than it was already. Moreover it tries really hard to be a tearjerker (and it feel forced, to me, at least), and I [i]hate[/i] this kind of manipulation. "Oh look, poor little kitties are dying in agony being ridden over by a tank!" No, just... no. Be a little more subtle, dear game, and then we'll see. Not to say there is nothing good: I mentioned some good parts and they're mentioned a lot in other reviews - it [i]is[/i] a conflicted experience, so it really is better to play [i]To The Moon[/i] - the game Rakuen tried so hard to copy - instead.
